content:
Posted: November 18, 2013
												Despite what some people might say, Fallout: NV is the better game compared to Fallout 3. It has the same basic "Fallout 3-esque" gameplay but it's much improved. They took many popular mods from FO3 and implemented them directly into the game and it's much better for it. I'd even go as far to say that "hardcore mode" is the way you should play Fallout: NV. It feels much better with that turned on...like a real wasteland and you're trying to survive in it.NV is exactly what Obsidian does best - They take a good IP and improve upon it in almost every way....especially the writing. Bethesda couldn't write a decent story to save their lives. Their writers are down-right horrible and every one of their games' story was a joke. They make nice lore, but they never write an interesting and involved story in a single game.The only thing FO3 has over NV is easy to see (literally). It's the visuals. FO3 takes place in a  ruined downtown DC area in the USA. Very iconic even to people who don't live in the US. The cowboy-esque visuals from NV are nice at times too, but nothing compares to a torn-up iconic environment most people have seen pictures of in real life.  It's the one real advantage that game has. Everything else though? Fallout: New Vegas actually does it better. Don't get me wrong, I liked Fallout 3 for what it was, but most everything was improved for New Vegas.Do yourself a favor and pick up NV today!

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Fallout New Vegas. The Fifth official installment in the brilliant Fallout series is wholly welcome.Carrying on faithfully the looks and feel of the much loved franchise it's a brilliant addition and definitely elicits a huge amount of enjoyment.The game depicts the adventures of 'the Courier', a man shot and left for dead in a grave yard in the town of Goodsprings. His quest was to deliver some sort of message... But it was stolen.  Venturing through the game you meet a wide variety of people and groups (including fan favorites such as the Brotherhood of Steel) and on your quest to recover the message you become involved in things much more important than you could ever have expected. The entirely new location allowed the Game Devs to include various new creatures and factions, allowing for interaction with strange new peoples.The visuals of the game are slightly different to it's predecessor Fallout 3, the altered, now orange-y colour scheme is a bit alien to the normal colour pallete however is not too disappointing. An issue with the landscape that I had, is the fact that it doesn't look enough like it's 'just' after an apocalypse. The environment seems a bit too lively, but in fact, it may have looked a bit too repetitive if it carried on looking like Fallout 3 (I'm excited to see how Fallout 4 will look with its rumored Nuclear Winter environment.)There are not many alterations to the gameplay as opposed to the last Fallout game - a style of gameplay which i have come to love with a passion. Fans of the series will be happy to return to using familiar mechanics such as V.A.T.S. which newcomers will quickly get used to.Basically, the game is pretty damn good! The new environment and story line, as well as glorious DLCs (like Old Time Blues) make it a must have in any gamer's collection.80/100

If god sent down a game it would be something that isn't so unpolished but dont get me wrong, if Jesus could send down a game he would of sent this game.Fallout New Vegas is a game that is quite frankly buggy and semi-broken but this doesn't sway me away from the fact that it is ever expanding and the gameplay and exploration and even the atmosphere is almost ♥♥♥♥♥♥ic, completed the game? that's no problem with fallout because of the vast array of mods up to download I'm actually half way through a mod called new vegas bounties II which adds 3-4 hours of gameplay with fully fledged dialogue and lip syncing.If I had to rate Fallout New Vegas out of 10 I would give it an 11, a masterpiece that is slightly inconvenienced by the occasional quest bug or game bug, I highly recommend this to anyone with a taste for a good open world game.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Fallout New Vegas is a very nice video game. From the story to the gameplay, it has eaten the past 100 hours of my life and I'm  very pleased to waste my time. From the art style to the music to the characters, it all just fits in so well. You could say that it's no different from Fallout 3 but unlike Fallout 3, this is a much brighter and much more difficult and polished up experience with only a few flaws within the game. The DLC is fantastic, offering lots of new content and areas to explore. However, there is the problem that it's a Bethesda game. Why is that a problem? Because it's buggy. You have to be careful with the game. If you can get over the annoying save bug (where you can't load your save, requiring you to start the game from the start in order to be able to load your oldest save), to some quest breaking bugs that require you to cheat in the console (I had this occur for me once, but still). The other problem is that the battle with Caesar is very very badly executed. But, that doesn't stop the game itself from being good. If you're looking for a very fun and enjoyable experience, I highly recommend you try it out. And the game itself isn't that expensive with all it's DLC anyway.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												Played 40 hours on my first playthrough, then lost the save file right before the fight at Hoover Dam.Now, one year later I finally build up the courage to start anew and begin an adventure that will help place Fallout: New Vegas as one of the most immersive, and addicting games I've ever played. The glitches give it that charm that lets you know not to take things too seriously, many laughs to be had. The game provides challenge as long as you play at least Normal and up.This game also gives you the option the literally play through the adventure, in many numorous ways whether it be what main story path you'll take (NCR, Caesar, House, You having an entire robot army)On top of that, you're free to decide how you will deal with every situation. You want to be a blood thirsty melee mad man? Maybe you'd prefer to deal with things in a more "peaceful" way, vanilla new vegas has been proven to be able to beat without killing a single creature or person (You can look up the YouTube playlist) Or like any regular person who likes the pick up Fallout, just wants to get 100 Guns and shoot any man creature or creepy ghoul proostitute, lockpick into everything (Which is nicely recommended) and all in all, have fun. The DLC is also all really well done and worth picking up. This game I recommend for everybody who has a brain420/10 changed my life.P.S. In H&H Tools Factory, read every single terminal, it's worth it.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2013
												TL;DR - Just by sheer length, you should be able to realize that I would recommend this game to everyone. This review is about WHY I recommend it so highly. I do not use the word "awesome" very often, but to say “New Vegas's writing and characters are awesome” is true. And I mean, they can create a feeling of awe in YOU. It is especially obvious in the companions that join YOU during YOUR game.SPOILER WARNINGS FOR FALLOUT 1, FALLOUT 2, FALLOUT 3, AND FALLOUT: NEW VEGAS ULTIMATE EDITION!It's easy to see why Boone is a great character. Or how much of a story you can actually give an eyebot. You should sympathize/empathize with Veronica, while being frustrated and understanding at the same time with what Christine had to do. Getting to choose which brain gets to be Rex's replacement, and finding him a mate in Roxie. Being able to help the Nightkin with a high enough science skill and Lily. Getting Dean and Dog/God to begin again. Helping Arcade and Raul choose their own future path in helping the wasteland. Aiding Follows-Chalk in deciding if exploring the "civilized world" is worth the time. Helping Waking Cloud with her family and uncovering the mysteries of her tribe's past.They are all interesting characters, because of their abilities to help you, and because they all have different stories. But Cass's story is different, even though it does not seem different. You find her drinking alone on the edge of New Vegas. Trapped between going home and trying to uncover the problems of her caravan business. You can help her several different ways. First you can convince her to go back home and not "sellout", or "sellout" in order to uncover what happened. And you help her choose how to deal with the assassinations, whether to take them to court and hurt them in their pocketbooks(the reason they did the assassinations in the first place) or deal in "An eye for an eye" justice, and kill them all. Regardless of your choice, she is never mad at you for helping. But you literally help decide what kind of person she will become. Now this might not seem very special. You are right, when only taken as the story from Fallout: New Vegas, her companion story lands somewhere in the middle to upper range.But Fallout: New Vegas is not the start of the series. And Obsidian had members that worked on Fallout 2(most importantly Chris Avellone, since he is also the writer of Cass and the Mohave Outpost where you find her, and he created Vault City – more on this later), and are close friends with the people that made Fallout 1. So it was not difficult for them to understand the entire narrative and expand upon what has already happened.To really appreciate Cass's complete story, you have to go back to the start of the series and understand your role in the Fallout universe. In Fallout 1(1997 in our world), the Overseer of Vault 13, sends YOU("The Vault Dweller") outside of Vault 13 in order to find a replacement for their failing water filtration system. The solutions to YOUR Vault's water problems cause the otherwise secret location of YOUR Vault to become known. The Overseer is angry that YOU have endangered Vault 13, so he sends YOU back out to save the Vault from YOUR mess. Once YOU are finally done ensuring the safety of Vault 13, YOU return home. The Overseer recognizes that YOU are no longer a Vault 13 citizen, YOUR travels have changed the person that YOU once were. He feels that YOU would be a danger to Vault 13's society. So after all YOUR hard work, YOU get exiled from YOUR home.Some of the other members of Vault 13 are angry at the Overseer for the choice to exile “The Vault Dweller”, and they all join "The Vault Dweller". They travel for a bit and eventually create the village of Arroyo. "The Vault Dweller" gets married and has a daughter. This daughter becomes the leader of the tribe. A generation almost completely passes before Arroyo falls onto hard times. They need a technological boost to survive.Fallout 2(1998) opens with "The Vault Dweller"'s daughter(the leader of the Arroyo tribe) explaining to YOU, her child("The Chosen One"), to leave YOUR tribe to find the required technology to help save everyone. Along the way YOU stop in Vault City. In the outskirts of town there is a bar. The owner of the bar is John Cassidy. YOU help him with his unfair debts. He wants to escape from Vault City now that he does not owe money and joins up with YOU. There is not much else to say. For the next 12 years(in our time) there is not much to talk about. John Cassidy was a popular choice to bring in YOUR party. He had a bad heart so YOU could store YOUR drugs with him without fear of him ever using anything but stimpack, but the man loves to drink. YOU can ask him what weapons he is good with. He tells YOU that he is mostly good with guns and knives, but is ashamed to tell YOU that he can use a spear(since it might make people think that his is just a tribal). The main character development seemed to be explaining to him that YOU are just a tribal, and he has learned his lesson about being judgmental of tribals.So why was all that back story about the stories of Fallout 1 and 2 important? And why did I capitalize all the "you"s and "your"s when talking about the Player Characters? I capitalized them to remind you that it was your choice for these things to happen. These are the canonical events. Even though you do not have to recruit John Cassidy, the official story states that you did.So jumping ahead to Fallout 3(2008). It is based on the opposite coast from the rest of the series, and barely tells us anything about what happened in Fallout 1/Fallout 2, like Fallout 2 did with Fallout 1. That is all that needs to be said about Fallout 3.Back to Fallout: New Vegas(2010). If you do not send Cass back West, she joins YOU. When YOU ask her about her name YOU learn it is Rose of Sharon Cassidy. Cass for short. YOU learn that she can use guns, knives, and spears. She gets annoyed with YOU, if you talk to her while high on any drugs, but gives you bonus for drinking alcohol. Especially her favorite kind, Whiskey, which gives YOU another bonus. When YOU ask more about her life growing up, YOU learn that her mother was sick and did not raise her much. Her dad just left one day, when she was young. All of the evidence should show that Cass is the daughter of John Cassidy. YOU!!!!!!!("The Chosen One" from Fallout 2) are the reason why John Cassidy leaves Vault City and Cass. YOU are the reason Cass's life has turned out this way. YOU are the cause of all her problems, just because YOU wanted a party member that was really good with a gun.The developers are the reason why Boone had a such a rough life. The developers are the reason why Christine was so obsessed with being in the "Circle of Steel" and solving the internal problems of the "Brotherhood of Steel". Even at the cost of her voice and her relationship with Veronica. The developers are the reason that ED-E is broken and that Rex is dying. The developers are the reason that Raul is locked up, or that Arcade has run from his past. The developers are the reason that Lily is going crazy and Dog/God's personality is split. The developers are the reason that Dean got caught up in the Sierra Madre. The developers are why Follows-Chalk and Waking Cloud are struggling with different aspects of tribal life.Sure, Josh Sawyer told Chris Avellone to do something with John Cassidy when the game was being developed. It is not completely YOUR fault. But you actually caused Cass to turn out this way. If YOU did not find John Cassidy's character to be useful, then Josh would never have told Chris to use that storyline from Fallout 2.YOU now recruit John Cassidy because if you don't, he doesn't help save the world, but still leaves his daughter and wife. Now this is the part of his story that YOU get to shape.Cass is one of the many examples of why I recommend this game to everyone.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
												This was the first of the Fallout Series that I've played and I am thoroughly impressed. The creators and successors of Fallout truly love their creation and put so much passion into their games and related items of interests. Only finishing FO:NV, I realise that I have only touched like 5% of the whole story. It made me curious and so I read the timeline of events in the whole Fallout universe and pleased myself with the reading of the whole story. I really enjoyed that as well!(From a first-time player of Fallout) FO:NV has great FPS gameplay including the VATS feature. The leveling, skill, S.P.E.C.I.A.L, perk and reputation system is vast and astonishing. I enjoyed starting new characters with high strength and luck and yolo it out in the Wasteland. The mass amounts of items, armor, weapons, ammo and drinks you can find is another aspect that'll make me enjoy and not get bored. Storyline is very non-linear and links up few quests so you don't have to got through too much trouble. The A.I is nicely designed for the era of the gaming industry when FO:NV was in. Companions are cool and there are many options to do with the companion (fight, stay, disband or just have a nice chat). Overall I just think FO:NV as an incredibly badass game.The main reason I played FO:NV was because of the massive hype for Fallout 4 that provoked me to try out the Fallout Series. I know now that I will definitely buy Fallout 4, when I have the money ofc. I am proud of Bethesda, Obsidian and the original creators Interplay. 10/10 I write poetry in my Brotherhood of Steel armor. Lasers are my ink. My enemies are my paper.

PROS:-Decent story-Brilliant, fun gameplay-Great characters-Great dialogue-Fun quests-Awesome weapons-Great DLC-Realistic towns (in terms of a wasteland)-Tons of mods-Has the same level of writing/characters as the original Fallout's-Weapon modding-Great soundtrackCONS:-Absolutely marred by bugs. Only real way to fix them is through mods, however the game will still be incredibly unstable. Note: If you want to mod the game, install Nexus Mod Manager, LOOT and Fallout Mod Manager. Be warned that modding incorrectly or not installing mods properly can break textures. Some mods may break interior cells as well.  Overall:  Great game, marred by bugs. 8.5/10

content:
Posted: October 13, 2015
												Fallout: New Vegas may seem like an expansion for Fallout 3 than a stand alone game, but that is only at first glance. Fallout: New Vegas takes the focus of the Fallout franchise back to the west coast and does so in a very good way. The story isn't exactly amazing, however it lends itself to letting you create your own backstory, and making your own decisions. There really isn't too much to hold you back from doing what ever you want? The base game alone has hundreds of hours of contnent in it, and has a huge amount of replay value, from four different major endings and dozens of smaller end pieces. That being said it is not without a few flaws: namely the glitichs and instability. It manages to be worse than its predecesor in that regard, as well as numerous bugs; some hilarious, some that can ruin a run through. The only other real complaint I have is that you CANNOT continue the game after you beat the ending, which is a shame. Still there is more than enough to do in New Vegas, and with all of its DLC this is a must have for any Fallout fan, as well as anyone who likes RPGs.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												War? War never changes. Neither does Fallout. Between Fallout 3 and New Vegas not a whole lot had changed. Heck, usually a sequel adds significant technical improvements. Not New Vegas. New Vegas trades out the setting for a slightly different one, trades in its story for something that Bioware would be jealous of. And adds a few new weapons and options. Other than that, New Vegas and Fallout 3 are pretty much exactly alike. And that is not a bad thing. I would have loved a more intuitive interface, or higher walkspeed, but I guess the developers held true to their creed of "do not fix what isn't broke." They also didn't fix was was broken, but big games have these small issues, and New Vegas is big. Huge. Ginormous. Not just in scale, but also in scope. There are so incredibly many things to do; if you'd try to do them all, you'd go mad. It is impossible to do it all in one playthrough; many quests have different angles and outcomes, and your alignment plays a big role. Oh, and this game isn't cushy with good and bad alignment. No, this game has a tonne of factions, and each keeps tabs on your relationship with them. You can suck up to all of them, or a few, or just go full paraiah and just kill everyone. Also, the game generally doesn't care about how you finish up a quest; just that you put an end to it. New Vegas is a true, and both technically and literally a sandbox game. Most of the world is desert. Miles and miles of barren, irradiated sand, rocks and broken roads. This is where the tedium sets in. Because for all its superfluence, there isn't much variation in the design. All the buildings look the same. Someone built the same dingy shack about 18 times over, all across the Mohave desert. You can only distiguish the various derelict factories from the name on the door. It's a shame. For all its complex relationship mechanics and over the top gore, it is easy to see where the developers cut costs.None of it really matters. The narrative just sucks you in, then spits you out to the side so you can go fishing for airplanes, only to draw you back in as you are rummaging through random hotel rooms. When you finally hit the climax, you'll have no idea about what and who you were working with. All the more reason to play it again, and waste even more time, looking for snowglobes in a giant desert while the future of mankind is at the mercy of antiquated fanatics who like to nail people to crosses for fun. Serious business.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												Fallout: New Vegas is all about more. There's more to do in New Vegas than in Fallout 3, its superb predecessor; there's more complexity to its gameplay mechanics; and there are even more secrets to uncover as you roam the postapocalyptic wastes. Fallout: New Vegas' familiar rhythm will delight fans of the series, and the huge world, expansive quests, and hidden pleasures will have you itching to see what other joys you might uncover. Occasional glitches and performance issues occasionally intrude upon your travels, along with the scorpions and geckos that might accost you. Don't let the quirks frighten you away, however: New Vegas' nooks and crannies are bursting with grimy treasures waiting to be dusted off and admired by intrepid explorers.There's a wild, wonderful world outside Vegas, just waiting to be explored.This latest trip into the desolate American landscape possesses many of the same elements that made Fallout 3 such a successful role-playing game, but its story doesn't boast as many memorable moments. The large-scale combat scenarios are less epic, and the surprises are less dramatic than Fallout 3's mid-game reverie. Nevertheless, the main tale provides a solid skeleton from which to hang a dumbfounding number of tasks and stand-alone parables. Many of these quests are lengthy, and great dialogue and good voice acting will invite you to learn more about the characters, as well as keep you wondering about what will happen next. A society of ghouls with pie-in-the-sky aspirations is creepy enough to make you squirm, yet blind devotion to their dreams still inspires empathy. Socialites in formal attire run a casino known for its creative menu choices, and if you play your cards right, you might get to make a menu alteration of your own. You investigate the disappearance of a sharp-tongued wife in one town and bring star-crossed lovers together in another. Some of the most fascinating occurrences are the wittier ones. During one quest, a robot with a specialized skill and a gut-busting name might offer a service that surely no game character has ever offered before. A poet in an unlikely place mumbles aloud his difficulties in finding the right rhymes. Like with Fallout 3, the greatest delights aren't in the central storyline but on its periphery.While the tale isn't as evocative as it might have been, the way it blossoms as you advance, giving you any number of ways to proceed, is extraordinary. The choices you make might lead to a dramatically different experience from another player's experience. The same is true of many supplementary quests. There's a ton of flexibility in how you might approach certain tasks. Maybe you'll fend off the robots defending a long-forgotten museum, but you might also steal an identification card that allows you to walk around (mostly) unharmed. You might provide a drug addict his fix, but if your speech skill is high enough, you can convince him to get on the straight and narrow. One lovelorn fellow will try to send you on a scavenger hunt for spare parts, but a high science skill means you can recommend another schematic and avoid the job altogether. However, there are certain cases in which the game funnels you down a specific path that might come as a shock if you prefer peaceful ends but are forced into a combat scenario with a single viable solution. And in certain cases, the quests just aren't designed particularly well. Searching for a key in a vault overrun with vegetation can turn into a major hassle. Avoiding an artillery bombardment isn't fun in the least and feels out of place given the measured pace at which you move. And an optional quest in which you hop from one computer terminal to another to isolate a virus leads to frustrating trial-and-error guesswork.Ghouls don't like it when you say 'eewww' to their faces. It's better to talk behind their backs at a later time.Large personalities give an edge to your undertakings. A mysterious man known as Mr. House presides over both the Strip, as well as your own adventures, and his singular focus on fulfilling his needs looms dramatically over the later hours of your escapades. The leader of a Roman-inspired legion is also an ominous presence and a violent counterpoint to the upright and learned leader of the Brotherhood of Steel's local contingent. A ghoulish ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, a potty-mouthed head waiter, and a wealthy-but-desperate father all make an impression in spite of their very minor roles. You might even find an interesting kindred spirit to accompany you. As with Fallout 3, you can bring a companion along with you; this is handy not only in combat, but it also gives you an extra inventory for dumping detritus. Interacting with your companion is simple, thanks to a wheel that lets you choose behaviors for your fellow traveler. You can only have one at a time, but you'll encounter multiple individuals willing to join you, and they all make interesting and funny quips when you interact with them. They also open up different quest opportunities, giving you a chance to learn more about what makes them tick.Fallout: New Vegas' major addition is that of faction favor. You establish a reputation with various towns and organizations by doing them favors or annoying them in some way or another. Which factions you align with has both subtle and profound consequences. If you're liked, a random somebody might run up to you bearing minor gifts, such as an iguana on a stick. (Mmm, tasty.) Or if you've gained a more violent reputation, a mugger might accost you with violent intentions, only to run off when he recognizes you. It's a pleasure to hear random citizens remark on how they feel about you as you pass by, even if the canned comments repeat a bit too often. (It's sometimes bizarre to hear two characters standing side by side deliver the same line, spoken by the same voice actor.)That Great Khan is no match for a sword made out of a bumper.Your faction relationships also have much more dramatic consequences on your adventure, opening up new quests while closing off others. The game is sometimes a bit opaque regarding how your actions may inadvertently affect the way a particular faction sees you, but this complexity manifests itself in awesome ways as you near the end of your travels. One great twist to this system is that by dressing up in faction-specific clothing or armor, you can disguise yourself and avoid a confrontation. Though, conversely, you might get dragged into battles against allies if you forget to change gear, which might damage a relationship you're trying to cultivate. This reputation system is a bit abstract, but it's a great addition to the Fallout formula, adding even more layers to a template already lauded for its flexibility.Glitches may give you a few minor fits, but the PC version of Fallout: New Vegas is not in the same rough technical shape as its console counterparts, possibly thanks to a sizeable patch delivered a day after its release. That doesn't mean there aren't problems here. We encountered some bugs, such as a friendly quest giver inexplicably attacking us, even though he didn't show as an enemy on the directional radar. Characters might still randomly freak out as if you're about to attack for no discernible reason, only to return to their normal locations a moment later and act as if nothing had happened. But we encountered only a few scripting problems, and the game never crashed. Most complex role-playing games suffer from technical hitches, and this one is no exception. However, the oddities in this version aren't exceptionally disruptive, which makes it easy to stay invested.Hacking is one way to solve your problems, but if you aren't good at it, there's probably another way. Or three.If you played Fallout 3 or The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion, which used the same game engine as Fallout: New Vegas, then you won't be surprised by some of the other minor foibles, although many of them seem exac

content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
 I just love this gameI played it without Steam some years ago for about 150+ hours and want to recapitulate this experience now with some Nexus-mods. Took me about 4 hours to get it running smoothly and without crashes, but it's totally worth the time and money!! For me  NMC-textures and Nevada Skies crashed the whole game. So this was a bummer. I recommend the following mods:  Western Sky!!  Active Wasteland  db enhanced Blood Textures  Full Character Overhaul!  Improved Sound FX!!  Sprint Mod  NVAC - New Vegas Anti Crash  EVE - Essential Visual Enhancements!!  The radio stations: CONELRAD and Old World RadioI also recommend to start the game in Windows 7 compatibility mode (Windows XP Service Pack 2).But also without mods and stuff this game is absolutely great and except the grafics totally up to date! If you're from Germany, be shure to buy the UNCUT Ultimate Edition!!For More Blood etc. open Fallout_default.ini Config file found in:...Steam\steamapps\common\fallout new vegasand find the following lines:fDecalLifetime=10.0000iMaxDecalsPerFrame=50change the numbers to:fDecalLifetime=720.0000iMaxDecalsPerFrame=512 Bottom line: This is one of the best RPG of all time and can keep up with games like Morrowind and Skyrim!Update: It's still running pretty good, but every 2-3 hours it's crashing...But so what?!Update after 150 hours: Done most of the side-quests and it's still fun to scavenge and explore the wastelands. There's sooooo much to discover and I realized that last time I played it I missed many many cool quests and locations.Right now, I'm starting the Dead Money DLC with my level 34 character. This DLC seems to be quite out of touch with the "normal" Fallout NV world. There's something about ghosts, radios which will kill you if you go near them (you're wearing a booby-trap-collar (Battle Royale?!), which will detonate on approach) and some guy is forcing you to enter the Sierra Madre casino with some companions...Mhh, I'm eager to find out how this turns out!! I'll keep you updated!Update: Okay, totally got addicted again to this game! Played every DLC and maxed my character out...Mhhh, let's see, how long it takes until I play it again :-DI WILL BE BACK!!Update:   Okay, maybe I won't be back, because, people, hear me out: FALLOUT 4 HAS BEEN ANNOUNCED!!!  So for all of you who can't wait, get this game and prepare yourself for the wasteland!!

content:
Posted: July 10, 2011
												A great FPS/RPG game.  It’s longer then most normal games with tons of replay ability and I’m still finding stuff I’ve never discovered.  NV also makes for a good follow up to Fallout 3, as they are build off the same engine and for the most part have very similar play style.  On top of that they reworked combat outside of VATS to make if feel more fluid with the ability to actually shoot down your sights even at low level over FO3.   Another improvement was to repairs for weapons were now you can fix a gun to max condition even with low repair  vs FO3 not letting you do that.  Lastly the change to companions and making them more useful over FO3 is great.  I liked having companions to help out and all of them have missions and stories their own that add even more to narrative of the world you play in.New Vegas does come with a little baggage (Few bugs/CTD) but other then that, as long you have auto save on your ok.  The only thing that puts me off little on this game is it don't really have the apocalypse feel as much as FO3 does.  I'm ok with the more old western feel but I do miss the large destroyed city feel most of FO3 had.  Mods also can help add to your world, change whatever you want.  You choose how things turn out but as always, war… war never changes.***9.5/10***

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												What an excellent game! I've played the entire Fallout franchise and in my opinion this game is what Fallout 3 should have been. Not to belittle the previous title in the series, in its own right it was a fun game, with an excellent storyline, but this game is truer to the original Fallout's quasi-Western-like feel. As with this games predecessors, you wander the apocalyptic wasteland, Immersive stories begin to emerge, with some pleasant story lines and character references to previous games in the series cropping up from time to time. In this game you will encounter a range of factions with whom you can choose to become friends or enemies. Many of the decisions you will make throughout the very open world/storyline will also transform your experience. One of the greatest aspects of this game being the fact that following the first playthrough you can make entirely different choices in your second playthrough (ie, appease a group you previously were enemies with on first playthrough or make entirely different decisions at key points in the game to unlock a totally different storyline) and enjoy an almost entirely new game experience - within certain limits. In some cases the storyline wont be as flexible as you may like and will limit how far your "alternative version of events" can go. There are other core features of the game that are equally important to mention - hidden storylines that you from time to time accidently stumble into in that second or third playthrough that will totally open up the game for you again and keep it fresh. There are numerous weapons, armour types, places to explore, people to betray, people to ally, monsters to kill, adventures to be had, decisions to make - and most importantly - the type of character you create as you play through the game. Do you wish to be hero and saviour of the weak? Or perhaps make sacrifices for "the greater good"? Are you super inteligent  and able to outwit those around you? Amazing with a rifle so that you can kill with a headshot before they get close? Perhaps you prefer to be a super strong brute that goes in close for the kill? Or are you the Rockafellar of the wastes - making a profit everywhere you go so that you can afford to buy rare and impressive weapons no one else has? The list of traits goes on, and you can choose to specialise in some or be a jack of all trades (and master of none) - the flexibility is all yours. Do you seek revenge? Do you crave power and influence? Do you hate bandits or perhaps wish to be one? The choices are *nearly* endless. The only thing I disliked about this game was not the game itself but the DLC. I only tried one or two of them and just could not enjoy them - even though they aim to expand some elements of the story line - I would consider giving these a wide berth unless you're particularly curious!For those of you who love post apolocalyptic themed games, sci fi, westerns, shooters, clever storylines, rpgs, action games, monsters, decision making and replayability. A highly recommended game that has been very cleverly made and well thought out. In most ways (aside from the FPS element) it remains true to the original Fallout games. A credit to the people who made it.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												What an excellent game! I've played the entire Fallout franchise and in my opinion this game is what Fallout 3 should have been. Not to belittle the previous title in the series, in its own right it was a fun game, with an excellent storyline, but this game is truer to the original Fallout's quasi-Western-like feel. As with this games predecessors, you wander the apocalyptic wasteland, Immersive stories begin to emerge, with some pleasant story lines and character references to previous games in the series cropping up from time to time. In this game you will encounter a range of factions with whom you can choose to become friends or enemies. Many of the decisions you will make throughout the very open world/storyline will also transform your experience. One of the greatest aspects of this game being the fact that following the first playthrough you can make entirely different choices in your second playthrough (ie, appease a group you previously were enemies with on first playthrough or make entirely different decisions at key points in the game to unlock a totally different storyline) and enjoy an almost entirely new game experience - within certain limits. In some cases the storyline wont be as flexible as you may like and will limit how far your "alternative version of events" can go. There are other core features of the game that are equally important to mention - hidden storylines that you from time to time accidently stumble into in that second or third playthrough that will totally open up the game for you again and keep it fresh. There are numerous weapons, armour types, places to explore, people to betray, people to ally, monsters to kill, adventures to be had, decisions to make - and most importantly - the type of character you create as you play through the game. Do you wish to be hero and saviour of the weak? Or perhaps make sacrifices for "the greater good"? Are you super inteligent  and able to outwit those around you? Amazing with a rifle so that you can kill with a headshot before they get close? Perhaps you prefer to be a super strong brute that goes in close for the kill? Or are you the Rockafellar of the wastes - making a profit everywhere you go so that you can afford to buy rare and impressive weapons no one else has? The list of traits goes on, and you can choose to specialise in some or be a jack of all trades (and master of none) - the flexibility is all yours. Do you seek revenge? Do you crave power and influence? Do you hate bandits or perhaps wish to be one? The choices are *nearly* endless. The only thing I disliked about this game was not the game itself but the DLC. I only tried one or two of them and just could not enjoy them - even though they aim to expand some elements of the story line - I would consider giving these a wide berth unless you're particularly curious!For those of you who love post apolocalyptic themed games, sci fi, westerns, shooters, clever storylines, rpgs, action games, monsters, decision making and replayability. A highly recommended game that has been very cleverly made and well thought out. In most ways (aside from the FPS element) it remains true to the original Fallout games. A credit to the people who made it.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												Fallout: New Vegas is pretty much the post-apocalypse game I always wanted. You have a gigantic world to explore, countless number of side quests in addition to the already meaty and choice-based main quest The gameplay is satisfying and is is the perfect balance between RPG and action shooter. The game easily has over 150 hours of content with all the DLC. It is a proper RPG, letting you play how you want, be it a suave diplomat, a sneaky thief, or a thug with a very big hammer, and has multiple factions to side with for the end-game.As someone who played the hell out of this on the Xbox, I got the game again on PC primarily for mods, and if anyone is considering re-buying for that reason, I whole heartedly say do it right now. Modding makes an already great game fantastic and utterly unique to you with thousands upon thousands of mods. Never a fan of any of the armour or weapons? There is probably a mod out there for you. Not a fan of the fast travel system? Get XRE cars and drive around the wasteland. Have Fallout 3 and want one huge game? Get Tale of Two Wastelands and combine them into one big game with the same character. Want the game to be less of an RPG and more of a shooter, with high damage numbers, sprinting and hotkeys for grenades and melee? There are indeed mods that do that. The possibilities are endless, and the main modding website for New Vegas is easy to use, letting you both manually install mods or have an app that does it for you if you aren't confident enough or unsure.  Pretty much any kind of mod you want, it's out there.The main downside to a game of this scope if the stability, and while generally stable there are some very common bugs everyone will come across when playing the game. Of course, if you have played any other Bethesda-style RPG you will expect this anyway. I made a post on the forums which has the main ones you will need to make the game stable and mostly bug free:http://steamcommunity.com/app/22380/discussions/0/522730700736948013/I can not recommend this game highly enough. One of the best RPG's of the last generation. If you want to see how awesome this game looks, check out my screenshots.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2013
												Fallout New Vegas really reminds the player of the original fallouts.Unlike Fallout 3 (which i highly recommend as well) New Vegas gives you choices that you may be morally conflicted with, yes Fallout 3 had choices in it, all good fallout games have, but New Vegas gives you more options. In addition to more choices the developers have introduced a reputation system, you do something good like help a community you will be liked more, but if you do things they do not like your reputation will go down. All of this matters in the endgame, who will support you depending on what side you took.Like many of RPG you will encounter people, you will talk to people. Throughout your travels you will meet interesting people you either like or dislike, all characters of importance are interesting, they have a story to tell, from Mr House overlord of the strip to the super mutants in Jacobstown.The graphics honestly are not anything to brag about. There is little change from Fallout 3, a few things have been brought over. But Fallout has never been known for their graphics, it has been for the story. If you are really bugged by the graphics you could just go and get a mod for it, there are plenty.VATS is back, along with other gameplay elements that made Fallout 3 popular. There have been changes made as well, more immersive elements have been added, like making ammunition, more crafting options, more weapons types, gambling and many more. I would not be recommending this game if there was no change, but there is change and it is a good change.Active community, Mods! The community is super active for mods, so many mods mods mods mods.Lastly the DLC. Lonesome road, Dead money, Old Wolrd Blues and honest hearts. All of them are good in their own respects but this review is looking at the core game, reviews for the DLC's will be on their respective pages or elsewhere.Fallout New Vegas is a game that is a game I will definitely recommend to anybody that asks.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
 Fallout: New Vegas Alright, before you read the rest of my review let me get one thing straight, on the whole "Fallout 3 vs. Fallout: New Vegas" argument,  I believe Fallout: New Vegas is better  in my opinion Fallout: New Vegas is better than Fallout 3, now hold on, before you call me the devil himself,  I don't dislike Fallout 3 by any means  , it's still one of my favorite games of all time, I just believe that New Vegas is better. I'll be going over my reasoning for believing that New Vegas is better and generally comparing it to FO3 a lot.First of all we'll have to go over some pros for Fallout: New Vegas Fallout: New Vegas Pros  Improved Gameplay Mechanics: One of the biggest improvements over FO3 is the improved mechanics such as the widely improved crafting system, the weapon modification system, ironsights, nerfed VATS, gambling, and etc. Improved Character System Mechanics: Faction system, better karma system, almost no essential (unkillable) characters, hardcore mode Branching Storylines: One awesome addition was the branching storylines (I'll cover the FO3 storyline later) one great thing about the branching storylines was the replayability, I'm about the do my 4th playthrough of the game, the factions you could choose from are the  New California Republic, Caesar's Legion, Mr. House, and Independant Vegas.  Modding: The game itself is amazing, and mods just make it more enjoyable, fix bugs, or add more content, it's all there within the Fallout: New Vegas modding community. Fallout: New Vegas Cons  Bugs: FO:NV, just like any other Fallout game, or Bethesda games for that matter, are plagued with bugs. Whether it's clipping into the ground, mission glitches that make them uncompletable, or missing textures, even though a mod has probably been made or a guide that can be found with a quick Google search. Similarities: One problem I had when first playing is how it was too much was similar with Fallout 3 such as the user interface and it just felt like a Fallout 3 reskin at first. Fallout: New Vegas and Fallout 3 Comparisons  World Design: I personally like the vibe that FO3 gives off more than FO:NV, while New Vegas gives off a "humanity rebuilding" feel, FO3 focuses on the apocalypse more and I personally like that about FO3, when I was gambling in casinos on the New Vegas strip it sometimes felt like a Las Vegas Simulator. Storyline: So this was my main gripe with Fallout 3, it's storyline, you would think I would have some choice, in Fallout: New Vegas there were 4 different storylines, all with different missions, and even side missions would affect the endings Fallout: New Vegas Verdict  9/10

Posted: April 30, 2012
												If you haven't been diagnosed with ADD prior to playing Fallout New Vegas, you definitely will be after playing it. There are so many places to explore, people to talk to, and things to do that it's difficult not to get distracted. But the game remains fun even when you happen to run off on some wild goose chase because the story flows so seamlessly. It never feels like you are on some irrelevant side mission. I love the stress-free freedom to do what you want, when you want to do it.The game left me in awe as to how intricate virtual worlds like this can be experienced in such stunning detail--definitely worth spending my time and energy. Its biggest disappointment is the inability to continue character development and exploration once the main quest is finished. You are forced to load an old save...

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Difficult to say everything that needs to be said, so I'll start with the easiest thing. This is my favorite game. I thought that Morrowind or Fallout 3 would be very tough to surpass, hell even Elder Scolls Oblivion was a pretty comprehensive experience, but no, Fallout: New Vegas is a masterpiece of gaming. The core game is great, but when you add the DLC it really becomes a massively worthwhile experience. Lots of moral choices, lots of options in how you can approach the combat, plenty of customization, single player even lets you recruit companions and equip them as need be. The settings are masterfully done, and have plenty of variation. Some stuff can plain creep you out, and some can make you want to just stand for a few minutes and take it in.  If you want a fulfilling experience get this game and play through it. There are enough endings and your actions carry over through even the DLC, so its easy to play 10 times through and have just as many final conclusions that are distinct from each other.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
												Fallout: New Vegas is easily and undeniably one of the single greatest games of all time (at least in my opinion). From the moment Ron Perlman mutters the simple opening line to the point in which you look back upon all that you have accomplished before your final decision at Hoover Dam, you experience a world filled with colorful landmarks and memorable people. On the surface, the game and its world seem crude, dirty, and vulgar but once that surface is cracked and you look inwards, you see an arrangement of mysteries and philosophies all waiting to be explored and experienced. Unfortunately, nothing can be perfect, every shining jewel is tarnished in some way or another- and in the case of New Vegas? The game is broken and unstable. You can not spend an hour in the game without experiencing the consequenses of an incredibly low budget and a development time of less than 2 years. Clipping issues, assets becoming distorted, quests not allowing you to progress, and so on. Not to mention the crashing. The game has some of the most insufferable crashes, often forcing you to sign out or restart your PC entirely. The final drawback of the game is its graphics. The game is ugly. It recieved no enhancement over Fallout 3. In fact, a noticeable percentage of assets and textures are borrowed directly from its predecessor. Of course all of these problems listed can be fixed with one simple method: mods. As one of the most heavily modded games of all time, its very difficult to run out of content, whether it be vanilla or added in at your discretion. Six years later and I still play this game regularly, and I'm hoping that Obsidian is given one more chance at the helm of the Fallout franchise.(Oct 2016) Nvidia and Windows have made this game absolutely unplayable. Can't even load a save, the game just automatically crashes. Thanks for the memories, New Vegas. We will never forget you

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												One of the Best Apolalyptic RPG games out thereStory 9/10Gamplay 9/10Replayable 10/10Achievement 7/10Fallout New Vegas is the fourth installment to the Fallout franchise. This game is a big step up from the previous game Fallout 3, one of my all time favourite games. It added more of a survival aspect and weapon upgrading to the already ideal nuclear apolalyptic world of Fallout. It seems that Bethesda wanted to take this game into more of a cowboy feel to it and  move away from the big city and the Brotherhood of Steel heavy power armour to the deserted Mojave wasteland with the NCR soldier look and The Legion Roman battle armour. Adding new and old weapons to aid on your journeybut still keeping the same look and style of Fallout 3. This game uses idea and references from the previous game studio Blackisle Studios plan for their Fallout 3 before Bethesda rebooted the franchise with more of a first person shooter.The story can be told in many ways and the actions that you take on your journey as the courier, the choices that you make truly make your character to survive the wasteland.At this time the game is easy and cheap to buy the game and all the DLCs and not break the bank but adding more whispers in the wind of the Mojave wasteland from the  science labs of Big Mountain to the cloud ridden get away Sierra Madre to the forgotten Divine, or to travel to an untouched land where the trees are green.I recommend this game to anyone that enjoys the idea of apocalyptic worlds where you are the creator of your free will.Cause.War, War Never Changes.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												This game is great, but it also has many, MANY BUGS AND GLITCHES. Pros: - Good Story - Many Quests, a lot more than Fallout 3 - Great Weapon Variety -  Good and bad voice acting - Many Followers - References to the previous fallout games - The best dlc's i have ever played - Many different paths and factions to follow - Great locations and level design  Cons: - Bugs, frequent crashing, glitches - Terrible Gunplay, you will probably rely on vats for many battles - Bad Graphics, terrible for 2010 - Character Creation is lackluster, your character will most likely not look like you  I know i probably missed many things about this game, but this is what i came up with. I recommend this game to anybody who enjoys the fallout series and the dev and published Bethesda, then this is a must have game. If you enjoy western rpg's there is no better developer and publisher, however this is developed by Obsidion, and is made in a different sort of mood than Fallout 3. This game is bright and interesting. Fallout 3 can be interesting, but it is most often dark and gloomy. This is great game that anyone who enjoys rpg's should buy.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2013
												I ♥ the post-apocalyptic vegas style, with the grimy feel of what once were grand buildings, casinos and neon lit streets overlooking a vast, scarce and dangerous wasteland, full of weird and sometimes wonderful things.Customise and create how *you* want to play by altering perks, skills and attributes from the beginning and developing whilst levelling up. Shun or gain respect with different factions and choose a path of destiny with the bigger factions that play core roles in the main storyline. The game is not really too difficult in normal mode but I enjoy playing this game in hardcore mode because it adds more realism to the gameplay, where carrying ammo is counted as weight, injuries take time to heal and ensuring to keep tabs on eating, drinking and sleeping enough.The battle system uses VATS, a targetting system that is entertaining to use if  zoned in on an enemy and they happen to have the weirdest expression or pose at the time!What really creates Fallout is the psychological dialogue of the characters encountered, giving clues to a history or a side-story in the background. Some of the characters are so quirky and memorable that it made me gain a thirst for knowledge about the fallout world. I think you will ♥ this game if you enjoy a combination of RPG, FPS, exploration. Plus there is a lot of DLC to dig into along with completing the main story and exploring all of the wasteland.Overall, this is one of my most loved games and I have to recommend it as one of the best games I have played, not just for the gameplay but simply for the character and role customisation that has been presented as an adventure. ♥

content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
Fallout: New Vegas is a Post-Apocalyptic RPG that is a great change from common Fantasy-Themed RPGsIn the game you play as a courier about 200 years in the future where america has been turned into a Post-Apocalyptic radioactive wasteland by a war with China in 2077. Small towns dot the lands, while remnants of large cities are ridden with bloodthirsty junkies and criminals. While there is so much danger in the world, there is one gem that sticks out and attracts wealthier people from all around: New Vegas. A city protected by a mysterious overseer called "Mr. House", New vegas contains gambling just as much as dirty criminals and squatters.You were delivering a package for the Mojave express when you were shot in the head and buried alive by scheming businessman and had your package stolen. You wake up in Goodsprings, a quaint town on the very outskirts of New vegas. The doctor patches you up and sends you on your way. Your Mission: find the man who tried to kill you and get revenge. On your way, you may be having to decide the fate of New Vegas, and maybe, the world.The Pros:The gameplay stays true to regular RPGs, with a balanced level system but a low cap at level 30. The game is easy to get used to and does have a more challenging mode for when you become a veteran at the game. Hardcore Mode is a mode that increases the difficulty of the game by giving ammo weight and adding hunger, thirst and the possibility of sleep deprivation. I dont reccomend playing on this mode on your first playthrough, but is a fun twist on the traditional game. The arsenal of guns is truly AMAZING, some obtainable through with expensive purchases while others you may have to do some hunting for. there are a large variety of locations in the game and there is even more if you buy the DLCs. All of them are great in my opinion but you may want to pick up lonesome road and old world blues before any of the others. Both give you interesting new areas to explore and cool storylines (lonesome road is a direct continuation of the story!) and maybe up to 10 hours each of additional gameplay. The game also has an INSANE amount of mods and a great mod community. Head over to the Fallout New Vegas Nexus for most mods.The Cons:The Graphics are a little dated since it uses the same engine as Fallout 3. The Game also does have a long tutorial period for learning the game, Which can almost stop you from replaying the game a third or fourth time. The "Dead Money" DLC is absolutely horrible, full of ugly puzzles which make you feel like you're not even playing Fallout, More like a horrible and buggy indie stealth-puzzler. The vanilla game is also buggy, some that can even stop you from progressing in the game.Despite these cons, Fallout NV is a great Shooter-RPG to pick up, and a cheap one at that! I give it an 8/10.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												"The New California Republic needs YOU strong!  Do not eat irradiated food!"Having played through Fallout 3 twice over the course of the past half of a decade, I was looking forward to giving Fallout: New Vegas a go but I always seemed to forget that it was in my library when I was choosing what my next 'main game' was going to be.  Finally, with the announcement of Fallout 4 being released in the near future, I pulled it together and started it up with the goal of completing it before the new release.  I was not disappointed.Fallout: New Vegas feels like a standalone expansion to Fallout 3.  However, this particular standalone expansion brings so much to the game that it may as well have had a 4 slapped onto the end of the title.  The roleplaying aspect is drastically improved with a faction alignment system, a balancing of the skills (all of them are extremely useful throughout the game now), and an incredible and deep storyline that alters the world and the ending based on choices that you have made throughout the game.  As opposed to saying that I enjoyed the story as I did in Fallout 3, New Vegas pulled me in and didn't let go until I'd finished the game in its entirety.The more action-FPS aspect of the game was significantly improved in this iteration as well.  Fighting outside of VATS seemed much smoother this time around and was genuinely enjoyable as opposed to merely acceptable.  Crafting was completely overhauled with several different skill lines unlocking hundreds of recipes that were invaluable at differing stages of the game.  The lands around New Vegas were a blast to explore and seemed packed full of life from one side of the map to the other.  Every trip I took across the wasteland resulted in discovering a new location to explore, a caravan being ambushed by the dreaded Caesar's Legion, or any number of other events that were a breath of life in the world.A great game, and one of my favorites now, that I highly recommend to RPG, FPS, and Post-Apocalyptic fans. I'll definitely be taking at least one more trip back into New Vegas to see what other events, quests, storylines, and endings I can discover by signing on with one of the other factions in the game.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												Orth, 3000 years in the future. The planet is a radioactive wasteland inhabited by ska-criminals, sentient rat mutants, and Fearum's deadly Waster clan. The Daybringer is the proxy agent for extrasolarian reverse-aging gas-cloud lifeforms which intend on re-arranging the events of all timelines so that only one timeline remains, freeing up valuable multiverse real estate. Jack and Jill are the most advanced paired AIs ever conceived, on a mission to sift through memories and sort out where and when The Techno Device is. Dzang-Sarang is an extradimensional refugee hoping that the other half of his body shows up at some point. The ruthless Praetarch Unless has made a deal with The Daybringer to spare this timeline, but at what cost? Dr. Tuce Dopeshow is the only man who has a handle on what's going on but he's been dead for centuries. You are Abe Stahl, a salt-and-pepper haired grifter who just wants a root beer. Chinese language only, all characters voiced by Frank Yang. 8/10

content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												A lot of people don't like this game as much as Fallout 3, but in my opinion I find New Vegas better than FO3. Like FO3, you explore a large wasteland and take on different quests, explore different locations, encounter different people/creatures/things trying to kill you, etc. I like New Vegas more because of its larger selection of weapons, cool DLC (My 2 favorites are Old World Blues and Lonesome Road) and a vibrant modding community that adds even more weapons, gear and the like. Also, there's a Hardcore mode where you really have to pay attention to your hunger, sleep and radiation levels, as well as not lug so much ammo around (ammo has weight in Hardcore mode).

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												I have looked at this game in my review list for months, of all the titles in my back catalogue Fallout: New Vegas is by far the most daunting. I feel that regardless of to what extent I praise FNV, I will still not be doing it justice.Fallout as a series has grown from some seriously humble roots, and what it has become is one of the finest post-apocalyptic open world RPGs to date. The world is alive, desperate, detailed, immersive and a true wonder to explore. Within this incredible world are some of the most spectacularly realized NPCs and stories ever conceived by Bethesda. The last time I remember being so aware of the lives around me was when I first played Morrowind.As if the vanilla game wasn’t amazing enough, the modding community is seemingly limitless. From tower defense, to a first person shooter overhaul, to countless add on stories and scenarios, there are hundreds if not thousands of hours of content to lose yourself in. The ultimate kicker here is that Fallout: New Vegas is CONSTANTLY on sale. And not just dinky 15% off specials, during any given steam sale, FNV is almost always on sale for 2 or 3 bucks at some point. At this price, it is absolutely ridiculous not to pick up this masterpiece RPG.

A lot of people have criticized this game because it had a smaller map than Fallout 3, that is a terrible reason to talk badly about this game. In quite a few of them you could even get your own room.Pros:One of the Best games of all time!Beautiful vegas setting!Lots of new weapons and combinations!Several different endings that you can choose!Only $10 retail and $2.50 during some sales!Cons:There aren't any unless the smaller map bothers you!All in all this is a 10/10 game and for only $10 it is literally a steal. number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												I really am in love with this game and the fallout series, just to put my bias out there. Pros:-Great storyline-Many likable and rather "hateable" characters that will manipulate your emotions and affect your choices-Karma and repuatation gives the game another layer, plays on your conscience constantly. -MASSIVE amount of weapons, armors, clothing, chems, ammunition variations, that can either give you an advantage or mess your day up!-Enemies' levels remain constant, so some areas may not always be comfortably accessed which really encourages you to level particular skills that may give you an advatage.-The wasteland is HUGE, maybe not as big as it was in Fallout 3, but it is big with many places to discover-Full nexus mod manager support, which gives this game so much more life; you can expand the selection of items, skills, perks, and game mechanics. Give the entire mojave a makeover, or implement zombies, the choice is yours! The modding community is very much active and helpful. Cons:-Game crashes. You will have a few, guaranteed. Not sure if there is a memory leak or not, the game does have a spike in RAM usage when loading new areas. I have 8GB and have not really had many issues at all. I personally only had crash issues related to mod usage. Friends' crash issues are with the vanilla game, do not know why. I think I can remedy any issues with a 16GB RAM upgrade. -Sometimes there will be bugs where you may not be able to access particular dialogue that will activate the next part of a quest, this has been rare in my experience and can only be remedied with a load to a previous save. So on that note, save often. -Without atmosphere mods (Neveda Skies is one of the best, also various ENBs are pretty cool) the vanilla atmosphere does not carry the same feeling as Fallout 3. I don't know if this was intentional, I get the impression that game-makers where trying to show an america where the world is very much accustomed to the new-world. -Not an issue for me, but the game can seem slow at times.Overall, this is an amazing experience that I recommend to anybody who has a little patience. The game gives the land of fallout, another breath of fresh air, which has been welcomed and embraced by many.Edit: Now have 16 gigs of RAM. No crashing issues what-so-ever.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
												Wow this is a good game. This was my first fallout game and I loved it. Now that I play other ones I see how different they are. Like in Fallout 3 companions have karma requirements which sucks. The music is one of the best parts. The mojave is big and sometimes empty and desolate. But the music helps with that even if it is. You don't know how often me and one of my friends starts singing I've got spurs that Jingle Jangle Jingle... Another good thing is companions, I love all the different companions. my only complaint is that you could have had more at one time. Also good job on rex and not making another dogmeat, like somebody! (Fallout 4) The main part I love about the game is how good it is to explore. At the beginning you can just explore and find random things and places. But once you hit level 20 you can get the explorer perk and do some hardcore hunting of places. For the traits in the game all I ask of you is to get the wild wasteland traits. It really adds to the game so just do it. Also get Fallout: New Vegas Ultimate Edition you get all the DLC's and it's just better. Also before buying it though check if it will play on your computers because some people say it won't, just fair warning. It may look like I don't have much time on it but that is because it doesn't count offline time.

												If I had one word to describe this game I would choose Spectacular! A lot of people have criticized this game because it had a smaller map than Fallout 3, that is a terrible reason to talk badly about this game. In quite a few of them you could even get your own room.Pros:One of the Best games of all time!Beautiful vegas setting!Lots of new weapons and combinations!Several different endings that you can choose!Only $10 retail and $2.50 during some sales!Cons:There aren't any unless the smaller map bothers you!All in all this is a 10/10 game and for only $10 it is literally a steal. number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												I have looked at this game in my review list for months, of all the titles in my back catalogue Fallout: New Vegas is by far the most daunting. I feel that regardless of to what extent I praise FNV, I will still not be doing it justice.Fallout as a series has grown from some seriously humble roots, and what it has become is one of the finest post-apocalyptic open world RPGs to date. The world is alive, desperate, detailed, immersive and a true wonder to explore. Within this incredible world are some of the most spectacularly realized NPCs and stories ever conceived by Bethesda. The last time I remember being so aware of the lives around me was when I first played Morrowind.As if the vanilla game wasn’t amazing enough, the modding community is seemingly limitless. From tower defense, to a first person shooter overhaul, to countless add on stories and scenarios, there are hundreds if not thousands of hours of content to lose yourself in. The ultimate kicker here is that Fallout: New Vegas is CONSTANTLY on sale. And not just dinky 15% off specials, during any given steam sale, FNV is almost always on sale for 2 or 3 bucks at some point. At this price, it is absolutely ridiculous not to pick up this masterpiece RPG.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												I really am in love with this game and the fallout series, just to put my bias out there. Pros:-Great storyline-Many likable and rather "hateable" characters that will manipulate your emotions and affect your choices-Karma and repuatation gives the game another layer, plays on your conscience constantly. -MASSIVE amount of weapons, armors, clothing, chems, ammunition variations, that can either give you an advantage or mess your day up!-Enemies' levels remain constant, so some areas may not always be comfortably accessed which really encourages you to level particular skills that may give you an advatage.-The wasteland is HUGE, maybe not as big as it was in Fallout 3, but it is big with many places to discover-Full nexus mod manager support, which gives this game so much more life; you can expand the selection of items, skills, perks, and game mechanics. Give the entire mojave a makeover, or implement zombies, the choice is yours! The modding community is very much active and helpful. Cons:-Game crashes. You will have a few, guaranteed. Not sure if there is a memory leak or not, the game does have a spike in RAM usage when loading new areas. I have 8GB and have not really had many issues at all. I personally only had crash issues related to mod usage. Friends' crash issues are with the vanilla game, do not know why. I think I can remedy any issues with a 16GB RAM upgrade. -Sometimes there will be bugs where you may not be able to access particular dialogue that will activate the next part of a quest, this has been rare in my experience and can only be remedied with a load to a previous save. So on that note, save often. -Without atmosphere mods (Neveda Skies is one of the best, also various ENBs are pretty cool) the vanilla atmosphere does not carry the same feeling as Fallout 3. I don't know if this was intentional, I get the impression that game-makers where trying to show an america where the world is very much accustomed to the new-world. -Not an issue for me, but the game can seem slow at times.Overall, this is an amazing experience that I recommend to anybody who has a little patience. The game gives the land of fallout, another breath of fresh air, which has been welcomed and embraced by many.Edit: Now have 16 gigs of RAM. No crashing issues what-so-ever.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												Very few games have grabbed me the way this one does. There's just so much to do, and that's before you start dabbling in mods of which there are many excellent choices, no matter what it is you're looking for. Yes, there are bugs. But by now the majority of them are hammered out, at least in my experience. New Vegas Script Extender and New Vegas Anti-Crash are must-haves and greatly improve the game's stability. The key here is exploration. Put one foot in front of the other for a little while and you're bound to find something cool to get involved in, whether it's a hostage situation in a ruined city or a showdown in a little desert town. The combat is quite fun, but it's the standard fare. You have guns, there are guys over there and ♥♥♥♥ those guys. Speaking of guns, there's an assload of them. Pistols, shotguns, rifles, assault rifles, SMG's, sniper rifles and even energy weapons, though I myself prefer conventional firearms, the energy weapons are still pretty badass. The storytelling in this game is superb, with little details everywhere. The story of The Survivalist in Zion Canyon is amazing to read through and experience as you seek out his journal entries across the little hideaways he's established throughout the area. There's also the little things like finding a skeleton laying on a bathroom floor in a tophat clutching a revolver that makes you wonder just what that poor guy's story was. The game manages to be dark and hilarious at the same time which is a tough balancing act to pull off.Overall this game is excellent and will draw you in and not let go. You'll be stuck on this for hours and hours and you'll love every moment.9/10

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												So what do I personally think of  "Fallout: New Vegas?"  Well, I think this is probably the best Fallout game I've ever played. Simply a masterpiece for the Fallout universe that fits so well, with a new main questline nearly totally different from Fallout 3. SPOILER, GO! ->  Except they both sorta still involve water at the end... Sorta.  With even some new creatures, and a new look at the way I saw Super Mutants, which in comparison to the once in D.C., they're just so... beautiful.  *Slow tear drop*  So if you like horror games, Fallout may just be your ticket to a few new scares from Cazzadors, Radscrops, or even Ghouls! Then you have NPC's. As there are hundreds of dumby NPC's like there are in every Fallout that lack every bit of social skill, there are a large amount of interesting characters with interesting names apart from "Novac settler." These characters with names such as Easy Pete, Mr. House, Ceaser, President Kimball, Boone, ED-E, and more are all unique. So every time you meet someone new in the game, expect a new personality to communicate with! Each one apart of a faction. Well, almost. But thats right! Because in this game there are loads of factions to choose from. Factions that each may just change the political map of the Mojave for the entire Fallout universe. Things you do have an impact on your character, the Mojave, factions, and just everyday Wastelanders. So if you wanna make it suck, you can probably do that. Wanna make it the next safe haven of happiness? Feel free! The choices are yours in this game. No need to really prepare for the future, because you're the one who shapes it here! Just be sure you're the proper level before hitting New Vegas. Especially do the same before you get any of the worth-while DLC as well. So for me, all of this just adds up to be my absolute favorite of the Fallout universe, since Fallout, to Fallout 3, and to now Fallout: New Vegas. *Cough* But still your average bugs of course. Pay no mind to them. *Cough* Note however this is all from past experiance on the PS3.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												After the wide critical acclaim and finacial success of Bethesda's Fallout 3, it was only a matter of time before a follow up was to be produced. This follow up developed by Obsidian Entertainement would not only meet fan expectations across the board but raise the bar of quality and world building for Western RPG's as a genre. What makes New Vegas a great game compared to it's contempararies is the level of depth and thoughtfulness when it came to presenting it's setting. The people, towns, and factions are all handled incredibly realistically, to the extent where each settlement has it's own food source and way of income. Comparitively in Fallout 3, such details are completely glossed over, leaving some very impractical settlements scattered about the wasteland. Since this game uses the same engine as Fallout 3, Obsidian had the luxury of improving where they Bethesda left off. As a result, players have the ability to aim down the sight of their weapons, switch between different ammo types, weapon modding, companion quests/companion perks, and a hardcore mode which offers even more gameplay mechanics to the mix. Personally, I'd say my favorite aspect of New Vegas is the thriving mod community that continues to still produce more content on already 100 + hour experience.If you're into games that present world worth engaging yourself in as well a wealth of opportunities for player expression, then New Vegas is definitely worth the purchase. Easily one of the best games of last generation.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
												I have invested 271 hours of my life into this game at the time of me writing this "review" and I can tell you from personal experience that, unless you have a raging desire to finish anything you start immediately upon starting it, you will find yourself constantly distracted from the main story line by little quests that you think you will finish within a few minutes only to return to the story line 20 levels higher than you were when you left. This game will make you a murderous hoarder whose only desire is to find the most effective way to kill an innocent civilian with the weapon you just obtained from the previous civilian that you totally didn't murder. This game is filled with "OH♥♥♥♥♥♥" moments from seeing a horde of ghouls in a dark sewer to meeting your first Deathclaw that just wants to hug you. You are able to join multiple factions in the game from the Boomers, a community of explosive-obsessed xenophobes, to Caesar's Legion, a society of slavers whose sole purpose is to merge all "tribes" of the wasteland into the Legion and control the wastes. Overall, this game is just ♥♥♥♥ing amazing at consuming your life and you should really consider buying it.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												Fallout New Vegas.I've spent a LOT of time with this game, more than I want to admit to, but one thing that's always, ALWAYS persisted through out this wonderful experience is the life in it.Now prick up your ears 90's computer game fanboys; this game is MILES better than Fallout 2, not to say Fallout 2 isn't a good game. New Vegas is just better.In Fallout 2, there was always this, this thing, the feeling of danger, lurking over your shoulder, ready to pounce for the kill at any moment. And while some argue that's a good atmosphere for surviving a nuclear apocolypse, it just kills the feeling of life. Everything's dead. That Brahmin's dead, Johnny Von Whathisface is dead. You're dead.Not so with Fallout: New Vegas.True to it's real-life namesake, there IS that feeling of danger, of forbiddeness, but that's probably mostly due to the gambling. See, while there are many things in the Mojave that can kill you instantly (Deathclaws), and many things that can scare you (Deathclaws) and just things that downright make you feel all alone and helpless, without anyone to help you (Deathclaws), there is always that little glimmer of life, like the feeling of old world charm rushing through you as you climb that first hill in Goodsprings and see The Lucky 38 shining in the distance, you feel, for once, a little bit of hope, in a world without care.Ain't that a kick in the head?
