content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Let me start off by saying this, if you can't decide if you should get the game or not, buy it! It's worth every penny. I didn't expect to like this game as much as I do. I constantly tell myself that I'll do only one quest, yet that's very difficult to follow through with. I'll end up spending hours on end exploring new locations, doing side quests, and just being an awesome wasteland adventurer. Whether which path you choose, good, bad, NCR, legion, or whatever other choice there is (there's plenty), the game never fails to satisfy. There are so many amazing things about this game that will make you want to keep playing. I recommend doing what I did and buy Ultimate Edition because it will give you all of the great DLCs and extra packs for a very good price. It also will help you at the start of a new game. If you dont have Ultimate Edition though, it's all good. The game is just as great with or without it. The DLCs are amazing, but if you don't have them you'll enjoy the game just as much!PROS: Amazing story, ALOT of side quests, many places to explore, ALOT of replay value (many different ending outcomes), plenty of humor here and there, Amazing DLCs, and pretty much everything else!CONS: I can't think of any. o:You will most likely enjoy this game, I recommend that you play it sometime. 9.5/10

content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												Fallout NV just one of those games that you can play forever (or untill you've killed everyone on the map).The main story and quests were awesome and interesting, but there're a few side-quests (''Beyond the beef'', ''Come fly with me'', ''I forgot to remember to forget'' etc. )  and DLC content that I've found far more interesting than the main story itself, especially the "Lonesome road'', which in my opinion could be easily one of the main quests in the game. Also i really love the fact that some of  the DLC have some characters that're connected to other characters in other DLC's, and because of this fact the Mojave Westland and the people surviving in it becomes even more interesting world to explore. Oh, and how could i forget the fact that when you reach levels 30+ you're starting to feel like an indestructible war-machine that can do and destroy whatever the ♥♥♥♥ he want. and have a LOT of fun doing it.Fallout NV is jsut one of those games that just throw you into their world, and never let go.

												Good ol' Fallout New Vegas! Let me start off with saying, I love this game. Now I know quite a bit of people which prefer Fallout 3 for its more post apocalyptic feel and just being how fallout 3 was, however I prefer this game. Now, although I will admit I have never played the original Fallout 1 and 2, I do know a fair bit, and really am looking forward to playing them, and from what I know, if you want to continue off from where Fallout 2 ended, or just want to get into more of a lore feel, this game is for you, not putting down Fallout 3, but it wasn't near the location of fallout 2, making it a lot harder to continue on the growing factions and people like Fallout New Vegas did. But if you're just here for fun, add mods and it can double the fun a lot of the times. There are some downsides to this game however. There are some technical issues, stutter, crashing and etc, but when looking past all these, its a damn fine game. However this is just my oppinion.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												The dark humor combined with a retro 50s vibe set in a futuristic world makes for a unique experience that's just waiting to be explored. Blowing off a Mutant's head with your Hunting Rifle while listening to your radio is throughly satisfying but be aware that this game isn't for everyone. If you've played Skyrim and are expecting more of the lively, beautiful and colorful landscapes of Tamriel in New Vegas, you're in for a disappointment. New Vegas is not pretty. It's run-down, gloomy, abandoned and depressing. But that's the point. You're supposed to feel isolated and feel out of place in the vast wasteland of Nevada. This is by no means, the game's con but rather, its pro. Obsidian nails the feeling of a post-apocalyptic world and the characters that fill this world is where New Vegas truly shines. You'll come across hundreds of NPCs, each with their own interesting, serious and often, hilarious backstories. It's these characters that bring the game and its story to life. On that note, the story is decent and keeps the game moving and depending on your choices, the game's ending will be affected. As a result, the game offers abundant replay value and can easily extend over 60 hours and counting (that's being really conservative).The choices you make aren't superficial like most games that advertise a "choice system." In New Vegas, your choices have hard consequences whether it's making a faction hate/like you or killing off an NPC. Yes, you can kill ANY character you see in the game (besides children, although there's a mod that allows you to kill children as well) so the choices are quite unlimited. Doing this can cause you to fail certain quests because a specific character is dead so you should probably think twice before letting someone bite the bullet. Graphically, New Vegas isn't that great. In some areas, it's actually pretty ugly with some sloppy textures and the vanilla models are pretty basic. The animations are a bit stiff and clunky as well. Other times, the game looks good and mods can do wonders for the game and completely change how the game looks, making for an even more immersive experience. However, New Vegas shouldn't be looked upon for its graphics. It should be judged by how much flexibility and options it gives to the player in terms of its characters and story. That's where most of the satisfaction is going to come from.If you're sitting on the fence for this game, go ahead and pick it up, especially when it's on sale. For it's occasional on-sale price tag of $2.49, this game is an absolute bargain. You may have to spend a couple of hours to really get into the game and enjoy it fully because I had to at first. But once I did, I couldn't put it down. Fallout: New Vegas is a really unprecedented experience and one that I feel many people should give a chance. I look forward to the next installment in the Fallout franchise.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												I have never written a detailed game review. I have written lots of reviews, but their short and generic. I am so enamored by this game i am going to write a full reviewFYI, I have not beat the game, or havnt even really touched most of the places or characters or quests. But after 25 hours with so much to do, I feel I can accuratly review the game.Overall Impressions:If you don't want to read a very detailed review of the game, just read this. If you want a detailed review (although u shouldnt be reading reviews and be clicking that buy now button) scroll down a bit. First off, I have not played FO3, so I have no way to compair weather its a better game than that or not. I had heard about fallout and the mascot for me was easily recognizeable when it came out, but I never had much of an intrest in the game or rpgs. Fallout:NV came out and when my friend got it for Xbox 360, I watched some and it looked interesting, but i was into other games and didnt want to play it. last christmas, while it was on sale, I purchased skyrim, my first rpg taste. Now I realize skyrim isnt as much of an rpg as FO but it got my feet wet, and I loved the setting, being an insanly big Lord of the Rings and Game of Thrones fan. However, i LOVE EFFING SKYRIM TO DEATH. That made me go wow! I bet Fallout is awesome if Skyrim is this good! So i saw it on sale over haloween and i picked it up along with the witcher, payday 2, dmc4. I played mostly pd2 and dmc and witcher and kinda forgot about FO:NV. However, when I did, I wasnt just hooked like i was 2 skyrim. This became the most fun, and overall meaningful game to my playing to date. All of the options are great, there are a lot of different factions all fighting and weaving in and out and picking some sids but not others is fun and challanging. I havn't touched hardcore mode yet but I bet its fun, I just want to focus on enjoying the game right now before I go shoot myself haha! Anways this game is amazing and a MUST OWN. Now onto specificsGameplay:+Many weapons+GORE+V.A.T.S. system is a great and not overpowered.-spritingThe gameplay itself is good, it feels good to shoot and the slight waver in your hand adds to the realism and I personally liked the added challenge. However, not being able to sprint, while not bad, can be annoying as I wish I could rush from cover to cover. I give gameplay 9/10Visuals:+Has moments of beauty+Destroyed wasteland is great and it all affects the mood of the game-runs on old engin so graphics look mostly outdated-character models look a bit stiff to meThis game is 4-5 years old and still looks good! However, it does look outdated and abovementioned stuff 7.5/10Story:+SO Many options+tons and tons of ways to progressTo me the story so far is great. Every faction is interesting and your personal story is very cool. The sidemissions IMO are better than main ones, but the main missions are great so thats saying something. 9.5/10Final verdict:9.5/10This is my favorite game of all time. That doesnt mean its a perfect 10. It has a lot of bugs and outdated models, but the game itself is what keeps me going. Anyway thanks for reading!HODOR!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												"Patrolling the Mojave almost makes you wish for a nuclear winter." This game can be taken very seriously. It is perfect for role-playing. You can choose multiple major factions that can change the tides of the story, or you can join side factions that have a deep lore. The mechanics also help role-playing. You can upgrade specific aspects of your character that measure the skills of said character. The dialogue system is also very good. It gives you choices of good and bad. Whether you want to be an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, or an angel, it is possible. The karma mechanic is a tried and true part of Fallout. "Hungry? Thirsty? Horny? Come to the Atomic Wrangler." This game can also be taken very non-seriously. There is hookers, gambling, and even sex robots. This game can be outrageous. Kill good springs. Join the Legion. Hack the world. Of course this path is harder, but it is leagues more fun. Overall, the game is 9.8/10. Might run into some glitches.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												This is currently the Steam game I spent the most time with. It added some interesting new features compared to Fallout 3 like better companion management and crafting. The story is not bad and has a lot of references to the older Fallout games. First I did not really like the game's main factions (Cesar and his Legion, Mr. House and the Strip) because I thought they do not fit too well in the Fallout universe. But later in the game when you get some more background information it plays out well. As with most Obsidian games also this one has some bugs and glitches. In my case the game sometimes crashed while saving or loading which forced me to restart and reload. No save games were harmed though. All in all a good game which I recommend to all Fallout fans and everybody that likes to explore an interesting open world. Comparing it directly with its predecessor I have to say I liked Fallout 3 a little bit more though.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												I have recently finalized my third playthrough in Fallout: New Vegas. Despite having played other Fallout games in the past, I intend to write a (short and sweet) review that addresses New vegas in a fair manner, and hopefully while attempting to remain unbiased. Here it goes!General notesFirst and foremost, as far as Fallout game comparison goes, New Vegas did not bring a lot of renewing elements to the genre. However, New Vegas does offer a very solid story, an immersive world and a fun atmosphere to be in. Moreover, the world surrounding the player is quite vast. Game worldNew Vegas contains a variety of dungeons for questing, looting and satisfying the player's homicidal needs. These dungeons come in various forms and shapes such as Vaults, caves and buildings. Additionally, there are faction camps, towns and similar places, where the player mainly interacts with NPCs. Above all, I consider "The Strip" to be an absolutely terrific aspect of New Vegas. It's quite refreshing to visit The Strip and have a change of scenery after poking around the desert for a while.QuestingNew Vegas provides a large variety of quests that initially aid the player in getting familiarized with the game, the various factions and the implications of making certain choices. More quests and quest lines will be available as the player continues to discover new areas, NPCS and factions. In my experience, it is not possible to complete all available quests in a single playthrough. This is primarily caused by faction disputes and the implications of completing a quest for a certain faction. As a result, an opposing faction might regard you as an enemy, and thus no longer willing to make use of your "services".DLCsNew Vegas offers a decent number of DLCs that will keep you going for a while. These DLCs often introduce new areas, weapons, companions and relevant quest lines. BugsNew Vegas is quite a buggy game, probably the buggiest Fallout game I have encountered so far. Game sometimes crashes when attempting to fast travel in the main world. This happens very often in the DLC areas. I have encountered a fair share of bugs with the companions as well. Sometimes they get stuck in walls, doors and rocks, or sometimes they just completely disappear when entering a dungeon for example. GraphicsWith regard to graphics, there is not much to say about New Vegas. The game simply does not offer a state of the art experience for the graphics enthusiasts out there. However, certainly not displeasing and good enough to keep the player going.Final verdictNew Vegas is an absolutely terrific game that provides hours of pleasure for the player. It offers a great story, immersive game world and a fallout experience that far outweigh the current bugs and not so advanced Graphics in the game. I would certainly recommend this game to new players and the Fallout veterans.-Sean

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												After the wide critical acclaim and finacial success of Bethesda's Fallout 3, it was only a matter of time before a follow up was to be produced. This follow up developed by Obsidian Entertainement would not only meet fan expectations across the board but raise the bar of quality and world building for Western RPG's as a genre. What makes New Vegas a great game compared to it's contempararies is the level of depth and thoughtfulness when it came to presenting it's setting. The people, towns, and factions are all handled incredibly realistically, to the extent where each settlement has it's own food source and way of income. Comparitively in Fallout 3, such details are completely glossed over, leaving some very impractical settlements scattered about the wasteland. Since this game uses the same engine as Fallout 3, Obsidian had the luxury of improving where they Bethesda left off. As a result, players have the ability to aim down the sight of their weapons, switch between different ammo types, weapon modding, companion quests/companion perks, and a hardcore mode which offers even more gameplay mechanics to the mix. Personally, I'd say my favorite aspect of New Vegas is the thriving mod community that continues to still produce more content on already 100 + hour experience.If you're into games that present world worth engaging yourself in as well a wealth of opportunities for player expression, then New Vegas is definitely worth the purchase. Easily one of the best games of last generation.

I havn't touched hardcore mode yet but I bet its fun, I just want to focus on enjoying the game right now before I go shoot myself haha! Anways this game is amazing and a MUST OWN. Now onto specificsGameplay:+Many weapons+GORE+V.A.T.S. system is a great and not overpowered.-spritingThe gameplay itself is good, it feels good to shoot and the slight waver in your hand adds to the realism and I personally liked the added challenge. However, not being able to sprint, while not bad, can be annoying as I wish I could rush from cover to cover. I give gameplay 9/10Visuals:+Has moments of beauty+Destroyed wasteland is great and it all affects the mood of the game-runs on old engin so graphics look mostly outdated-character models look a bit stiff to meThis game is 4-5 years old and still looks good! However, it does look outdated and abovementioned stuff 7.5/10Story:+SO Many options+tons and tons of ways to progressTo me the story so far is great. Every faction is interesting and your personal story is very cool. The sidemissions IMO are better than main ones, but the main missions are great so thats saying something. 9.5/10Final verdict:9.5/10This is my favorite game of all time. That doesnt mean its a perfect 10. It has a lot of bugs and outdated models, but the game itself is what keeps me going. Anyway thanks for reading!HODOR!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												The dark humor combined with a retro 50s vibe set in a futuristic world makes for a unique experience that's just waiting to be explored. Blowing off a Mutant's head with your Hunting Rifle while listening to your radio is throughly satisfying but be aware that this game isn't for everyone. If you've played Skyrim and are expecting more of the lively, beautiful and colorful landscapes of Tamriel in New Vegas, you're in for a disappointment. New Vegas is not pretty. It's run-down, gloomy, abandoned and depressing. But that's the point. You're supposed to feel isolated and feel out of place in the vast wasteland of Nevada. This is by no means, the game's con but rather, its pro. Obsidian nails the feeling of a post-apocalyptic world and the characters that fill this world is where New Vegas truly shines. You'll come across hundreds of NPCs, each with their own interesting, serious and often, hilarious backstories. It's these characters that bring the game and its story to life. On that note, the story is decent and keeps the game moving and depending on your choices, the game's ending will be affected. As a result, the game offers abundant replay value and can easily extend over 60 hours and counting (that's being really conservative).The choices you make aren't superficial like most games that advertise a "choice system." In New Vegas, your choices have hard consequences whether it's making a faction hate/like you or killing off an NPC. Yes, you can kill ANY character you see in the game (besides children, although there's a mod that allows you to kill children as well) so the choices are quite unlimited. Doing this can cause you to fail certain quests because a specific character is dead so you should probably think twice before letting someone bite the bullet. Graphically, New Vegas isn't that great. In some areas, it's actually pretty ugly with some sloppy textures and the vanilla models are pretty basic. The animations are a bit stiff and clunky as well. Other times, the game looks good and mods can do wonders for the game and completely change how the game looks, making for an even more immersive experience. However, New Vegas shouldn't be looked upon for its graphics. It should be judged by how much flexibility and options it gives to the player in terms of its characters and story. That's where most of the satisfaction is going to come from.If you're sitting on the fence for this game, go ahead and pick it up, especially when it's on sale. For it's occasional on-sale price tag of $2.49, this game is an absolute bargain. You may have to spend a couple of hours to really get into the game and enjoy it fully because I had to at first. But once I did, I couldn't put it down. Fallout: New Vegas is a really unprecedented experience and one that I feel many people should give a chance. I look forward to the next installment in the Fallout franchise.

Posted: November 20, 2014
												Good ol' Fallout New Vegas! Let me start off with saying, I love this game. Now I know quite a bit of people which prefer Fallout 3 for its more post apocalyptic feel and just being how fallout 3 was, however I prefer this game. Now, although I will admit I have never played the original Fallout 1 and 2, I do know a fair bit, and really am looking forward to playing them, and from what I know, if you want to continue off from where Fallout 2 ended, or just want to get into more of a lore feel, this game is for you, not putting down Fallout 3, but it wasn't near the location of fallout 2, making it a lot harder to continue on the growing factions and people like Fallout New Vegas did. But if you're just here for fun, add mods and it can double the fun a lot of the times. There are some downsides to this game however. There are some technical issues, stutter, crashing and etc, but when looking past all these, its a damn fine game. However this is just my oppinion.

Departing from the traditional Fallout scene of 1950's cold-war-turned-hot retrofuturism, this strong western post-apocalyptic story starts with you getting shot in the head, and it gets worse from there. Not gonna get into the story, what I am gonna get into is how EVERY decision you make WILL affect the ending. If you look after your companions and help setllements, they will get happy endings that will bring tears to your eyes. You can feel a real connection to everything, and it makes you want to explore and take different paths more and more.Don't even get me started on the DLC. They even connected that to the main story. You can ask chars in different DLC's what the think about the whole thing. So much detail and so many options are simply nonexistant these days.11/10. I mean it. Above and beyond. We will never get a Fallout game as good as this again.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												TL/DR: 9/10A different take on the franchise, New Vegas takes you into the west. One of the most appealing RPGs for a broad audience. If you play shooters, this game has alright shooting mechanics with true iron sights, unlike Bethesda's Fallout 3. If you like traditional RPGs, this is still a great addition with impactful dialogue trees and awestruck stories. You can side with three different main questlines, each with amazing characters and vibes. If you don't like the graphics, get some mods. Game can look better than Fallout 4 and still be 6 years old. If you don't like the vanilla weapons, armor, textures, npcs, voices, there are thousands of mods online that change just that with specific rifles and companion mods. The level-up system is very impactful, every single perk you can choose can bend the game. To name a few, you can be able to create ammunition out of broken weapons,  to repair a hunting rifle with a different rifle, and many more. I've sunk over 400 hours into this game and I can't say that about Fallout 4. This game is truly a masterpiece by Obsidian Entertainment and should set the bar for other RPGs. 9/10

												I figured I'd finally review this game. This is coming from someone who had trouble getting into the Fallout series for years: This game is a gateway drug to the series.I love the setting, the characters, and the plethora of interesting mods that have been out for the game for a long while now. You can choose to join a legion of Trump supporters...I mean dangerous barbarians bent on wiping out the new civilization around New Vegas, the new military which has broken and divided leadership but means well for the people....or you could just screw them both over and go the independent path. There are plenty of fun side quests and DLC that will give you hours of immersive entertainment.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2013
												Fallout: New Vegas is a game set in the Fallout Universe, with the Oblivion/Gamebryo engine. It is in full 3D and you can play in 1st or 3rd person. This is a deep RPG with plenty of moral choices, tons of weapons and equipment, lots of locations and side quests, as well as a main quest line with multiple solutions / choices, and tons of companions. You are the Courier, left for dead in a shallow grave in the middle of nowhere. You recovered and want to find out why they robbed you and why you were saved. You will end up exploring the Wastelands around New Vegas. The Fallout RPG system is in full effect, and the background is pretty amazing. There are also 4 DLCs that adds more quests, and when you're done with those, there are user-created mods available. This game is easily worth HUNDREDS of hours playing, more if you try out multiple characters with different specialities, and should not be missed.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Fallout New Vegas is yet another game about Skyrim with guns, but this one is different, and in a lot of good ways, the world created is a charming yet surprisingly deep land of politics and interesting characters all around.Instead of writing an essay about this i'm going to create a list of Positives and Negatives, I know when you're just looking to see if a game is worth playing you usually don't want to read all that much.Positives- The story always seems to be moving forwards and never seems to slow down always introducing new and interesting characters to meet.- The art style is beautiful, the world in general is extremely bright and colourful and everything is outline with more of a red tone than most games, this helps to differentiate its style from the crowd and really makes it a pleasure to view.- The characters are all interesting and I always found myself wanting to learn more about them and their origins.- The relationship between Boone and his wife is great.Negatives- The relationship between Boone and his wife might turn off some viewers.- The 'shooting' dynamic is interesting in some areas but it does get rid of some of the tension from certain battles.- The game ends on an extreme cliffhanger- Sound was nothing special.I would recommend New Vegas to most people if only because it is extremely short at this stage, it won't take you long to power through the 30000 quests, however if you don't like cliffhangers you should definitely hold off on playing New Vegas

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												Fallout: New Vegas, oh boy where should I start? Probaly a short bit about the story.WARNING! IF YOU DON'T WANT TO GET THE GAME SPOILED DON'T READ BEYOND THIS POINT! The game takes places in the mohave wasteland, an area around the remains of las vegas after the great war. Your a courier on a mission to deliver a mysterious platinum chip to the city of New Vegas, but your stopped by a man called Benny and his crew. They want the chip your delivering, so they knock you out and ties your hands so you can't fight back. When you wake up you see Benny pointing his trusty gun at you and shoots you in the head twice, they leave you for dead but you get saved by a mysterious robot known as Victor and he takes you to doctor Mitchel in the town of Goodsprings. Now you'r on a journey through the mohave wasteland to take back the mysterious platinum chip and get revenge on the man who tried to kill you.               Pros:                    + Good Soundtrack On The Radio Stations                    + The Story Is Amazing                    + The Humor In Some Parts Of The Game Is Really Funny                    + You Can Mod The Game To Your Hearts Wishes                    + The Detail Put Into The Game Is Just Splendid                    + The Graphics, Its A Improvment From Fallout 3              Cons:                    - You Can't Really Sprint But There Are Mods For This That Adds It.                    - Companion Ai At Times Loves To Block Doorways Infront/Behind You. Well thats about it for me, for me this game will always beat fallout 4 story wise, and I would truly love to see obsidian entertainment make another fallout game like this one day. I give Fallout: New Vegas a 9.5/10, If your a fan of Bethesda games or just First Person RPG's This game is for you.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												Warning: Disliking this game is punishable by death.Methods of execution include being forced to take part in a "lottery" by Caesar's Legion, viciously mauled by a literal pack of Deathclaws, swarmed by poisonous Cazadores, or being thrown off Hoover Dam. Fun!So take the superb writers and designers who were behind the original two Fallout games (who also did other great RPG's like Planescape: Torment and KOTOR 2) and mix it with the gameplay of Bethesda's Fallout 3. The result is a game that, at first, is a bit annoyingly linear, but opens up later once you eventually find your way into New Vegas itself. But you also get a game that is overflowing with sidequests, dark humor, and neat little bonuses found all over the world much as you would in Fallout 2. In fact, there is so much to do here I am not positive I've actually seen everything there is to see in this game despite having 100% completed it.Obsidian, of course, is a developer that is rather infamous for bugs in their games, and there are some to be found here as well. As usual, save early and save often just in case something breaks or crashes, but usually that won't happen too often. It will probably happen more if you fill this game with mods like I and many others love to do, but that's something you will have to accept because mods make this already great game even bigger and better.So if you like the Fallout series, you... probably have already played this, actually. If you haven't, then you should. Otherwise you too might find yourself digging a shallow grave in the middle of the Mojave desert. o_o

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
 Fallout: New Vegas  It is a production created by Obsidian Entertainment in partnership with Bethesda Softworks. And so it should remain. The game is set in the Mojave Wasteland, and  we play as a Courier who was shot and rescued by a local robot and doctor. New Vegas area are embraced by the war between the New California Republic (NCR), Caesar's Legion and the inhabitants of New Vegas. The story is great and our every choice matters at the end of our story. Sound system as in any Fallout is great, but the songs are often repeated and can be boring. Fallout is guided by that we do not have to do the main storyline at once, we can go off to explore the area. And there is a lot to explore, some of the locations it may be a simple hut but sometime it may be a large warehouse or vault with his own lore and quests. List of weapons is huge. From the usual guns after laser or plasma equipment. There are also melee weapons. Graphically, its do the trick but you can always improve it through NexusMods. The game besides the normal mode its also offers a hardcore mode. It is much harder than usual because the game change into a typical survival game. Our character must drink and eat in order to survive in this world. In my opinion this is one of the best productions I played. Finally a game where our choices are important not like in a Telltale games or new Fallout. That is why I highly recommend this production if you still have not played it. I spent many hours in it and have no regrets because I had a lot of fun.  Lonesome Road  This is one of the best additions to the game. I highly recommend it is incredibly atmospheric and character Courier Six is very intriguing. Also, the location is really well chosen.  Old World Blues  In this DLC move to the Big MT research crater. It offers a large map to explore, although the story is good gameplay itself is boring also we can get to this location by incident with a low level and you cant laave this location until you finish the DLC so beware of satellite and and do not click on it. :D  Honest Hearts  Welcome to the Zion Canyon area which is a war between tribes. The story od this DLC is good as well as the character of Joshua Graham is a really interesting person. Map is quite a big but most locations do not offer a lot of experience.  Dead Money  The least popular DLC for this game. I do not know why I personally liked. We come around in the Sierra Madre Casino totally helpless and without our equipment. The game most of the time based on an stealth due to tough opponents. The story is pretty cool and a little creepy. Gun Runners’ Arsenal  Regular addition offering new unique weapons and challenges. And that's it.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
 Fallout New Vegas: THE GAME THAT FALLOUT 3 SHOULD HAVE GOD-DAMN BEEN! Where, do I even start on this beauty of the game? I guess I should state that this game, has everything that Fallout 3 stripped from Fallout 2 and them some. This game just absolutely masterpiece that Fallout 3 failed to be. Yet we have Bethesda Fanboys thinking Fallout 3 and Fallout 4 are the epitomy of gaming. (Seriously though, I don't mind if you like Fallout 3 and 4 but to be honest, I don't feel they are real Fallout games)Okay, this game improved the gunplay, by so much. Iron sights may not be much, but it sure does help when you are trying to shoot the thing with the biggest weapon or the biggest fists or the biggest pinchers. Not to mention, there are plenty of beautiful, powerful, and unique guns in this game PLUS plenty of actual Unique/Legendary weapons such as Maria, Esther, This Machine, Dinnerbell, Alien Blaster, AER14, etc. Also, all the guns handle greatly compare to the ones in Fallout 3 which had the spread of the circumference of Mars.How about the RPG elements? Well, let me assure you, this game actually has those AND has plenty of choices to make in the wasteland that effects who has a ♥♥♥♥♥ier life. Plus, this game has plenty perks and traits that affect gameplay to the point of changing the Wasteland overall. Goodbye Fallout 3's Daddy's Girl (+5 to Science, +5 to Medicine) and say hello to Cowboy (Increased damage to western themed weapons such as repeaters, revolvers, knifes, dynamite, and more.) Did I also mention you can flirt with a gay and gorgeous scientist name Arcade Gannon? (Of course, that's only if you are into that kind of thing.) New Vegas, is also, a more direct continuation off of Fallout 1 and 2 as New Vegas has many of the elements and ideas that Van Buren (the original and cancelled Fallout 3) had.The environment this time around however, is kind of boring. Aside from the town's and settlements, the game should just be desert simulator. Places like New Vegas, Primm, Goodsprings, The Fort, Hoover Dam, are all great but at that same time, the surrronding areas have very little to them to make them really unique and the game lacks that true post-apocolyptic feel that Fallout 3 managed to catch so wonderfully but the game explains why the whole Mojave Wasteland isn't a massive ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.Now, for the DLC's that come with this pack.Dead Money is a great idea, that was poorly executed. The game's crappy stealth and overall run and gun feel, makes Dead Money not so great. However, it's story and characters are great. The story is about how you and 3 others attempt to rob the Sierra Madre casino after being captured by a crazy old guy. I won't spoil anything because boy would I end up spoiling everything about this DLC. Aside from what I mentioned above the weapons are really good. The Automatic rifle (The WWII BAR) boasts a beautiful DPS and great feel to it. The Holorifle, is a quite different energy weapon that is pretty much a damage-over-time shotgun that fires slug holographic rounds at your enemies.Honest Hearts is probably the weakest DLC but is still good. Beautiful environment with a somewhat boring story but once again, great weapons. The story is this, 2 tribes are fighting over Zion National park, the Sorrows, and the White Legs. With the help the Dead Horses and 2 New Cannanites, they are able to hold Zion National Park. However, they can justt barely do this. You, who was involved in an accident involving a caravan, go and help, decide the fate of Zion. The weapons... Tommy Gun, M1911, Tomahawks, War Clubs. Enough said. Old World Blues is by far, the most outstanding DLC as it involves the long forgotten Big Mountian which houses the world's greatest minds. After the nukes fell, the never left Big MT and they lobotimized themselves to become robots. You are abducted by them and theyn forcibly lobotomized you. This DLC, addes plenty of amazing perks, weapons, and enemies to the mix in BIG MOUNTAIN! The place clearly feels ♥♥♥♥ing awesome! Robots everywhere and you are allowed all the weapons you can bring to fill them with holes or vaporize them. Let me just say, you will get plenty of new weapons that will help your build in some way. The dialouge and story, while crazyily stupid and comedic, can have it's momentsLonesome Road is the big finale. Journey into the  Capital Wasteland  Divide to find a mysterious character who just wants to talk. Or kill you. Or nuke your faction. Or steal your robro! Lonesome Road lacks in story and makes up for that in grand scale badassitude, weapons, and challenge. Let me just say you will be getting Flare Rocket Launchers, Shoulder Mounted Machine guns, and more and you are sure as hell going to need them against all those Deathclaws and Ghouls armed with the same weapons. Hope you enjoy playing as swiss cheese!New Vegas is amazing. Everything about it is just amazing. Better gunplay, better RPG elements, more interaction, a true choice to be Satan himself if you so please or the Messiah. New Vegas shows what can be done should Obsidian take control of the Fallout series. RATINGS FOR BASE GAME PLUS DLCS FALLOUT NEW VEGAS 9/10DEAD MONEY 6/10HONEST HEARTS 6/10OLD WORLD BLUES 9.5/10LONESOME ROAD 7/10

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
 Fallout: New Vegas  It is a production created by Obsidian Entertainment in partnership with Bethesda Softworks. And so it should remain. The game is set in the Mojave Wasteland, and  we play as a Courier who was shot and rescued by a local robot and doctor. New Vegas area are embraced by the war between the New California Republic (NCR), Caesar's Legion and the inhabitants of New Vegas. The story is great and our every choice matters at the end of our story. Sound system as in any Fallout is great, but the songs are often repeated and can be boring. Fallout is guided by that we do not have to do the main storyline at once, we can go off to explore the area. And there is a lot to explore, some of the locations it may be a simple hut but sometime it may be a large warehouse or vault with his own lore and quests. List of weapons is huge. From the usual guns after laser or plasma equipment. There are also melee weapons. Graphically, its do the trick but you can always improve it through NexusMods. The game besides the normal mode its also offers a hardcore mode. It is much harder than usual because the game change into a typical survival game. Our character must drink and eat in order to survive in this world. In my opinion this is one of the best productions I played. Finally a game where our choices are important not like in a Telltale games or new Fallout. That is why I highly recommend this production if you still have not played it. I spent many hours in it and have no regrets because I had a lot of fun.  Lonesome Road  This is one of the best additions to the game. I highly recommend it is incredibly atmospheric and character Courier Six is very intriguing. Also, the location is really well chosen.  Old World Blues  In this DLC move to the Big MT research crater. It offers a large map to explore, although the story is good gameplay itself is boring also we can get to this location by incident with a low level and you cant laave this location until you finish the DLC so beware of satellite and and do not click on it. :D  Honest Hearts  Welcome to the Zion Canyon area which is a war between tribes. The story od this DLC is good as well as the character of Joshua Graham is a really interesting person. Map is quite a big but most locations do not offer a lot of experience.  Dead Money  The least popular DLC for this game. I do not know why I personally liked. We come around in the Sierra Madre Casino totally helpless and without our equipment. The game most of the time based on an stealth due to tough opponents. The story is pretty cool and a little creepy. Gun Runners’ Arsenal  Regular addition offering new unique weapons and challenges. And that's it.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2013
												Surprisingly, this game was heavily criticised by Fallout fans, for being no where near as big as Fallout 3. Personally, I think New Vegas is the better of the two, and here's why.New Vegas, whilst it isn't as large as Fallout 3, still packs an awful lot of content into it's self. Whilst most of the map is a barren landscape, New Vegas is FULL of hiden quests, items, easter eggs and just swarming with things to do.Whilst it doesn't add much new to the Fallout series, in no means does it feel like a Fallout 3 copy. The story is great, full of twists and turns and most importatnly, player options. You get to choose how you want the grand finale to go, wheter it's the easiest way or the hardest. After you complete the main Act's, you still have a ton of places to explore, quests to solve, and DLC to download!My only problem with this game, is linked quests. For example, to progress one Main Act quest, you must complete either a very long side quest, or various little side quests that usually offer no impact on the player or story. This is not a fun way to play, and it feels like the game is forcing these quests on me, rather than letting me have the freedom of choice, like the title the game holds dear to its self.+ Story is very interesting, player involvement heavily influences it+ Hundreds of hours of content, including 6 DLC expansions+ You really feel as if you make in impact in the game universe+ The Wild Wasteland perk. Nuff said.- Alot of grinding is required for some parts of the game- Enforced quests are not fun- AI is sometimes sloppy, but nothing too major9.5/10

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												If you're a newcomer to the Fallout series or someone who is a fan of old fashioned RPGs, I would highly recommend New Vegas. Not many games make you feel like your choices have weight and impact the world around you. Political factions are portrayed objectively, each having positives and negatives. The theming and light anachronisms really make the game feel like a topsy turvy wild adventure. The modding community is massive too, so you'll be able to have even more hours of fun with this one. All in all, one of my favorite games, and one of the best I've ever played. More quests and more fun than Fallout 3. Between the way that the developers utilized the engine's resources, the established lore, and the mechanics imposed by Bethesda, I think they did a near as perfect job as possible in making this game. 10/10

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2014
												This is one of my favorite games on steam. I can't seem to decide which game is better this or Fallout 3.(EXCEPT THIS GAME HAS MORE REPLAY ABILITY) This games brings a lot to the playing field if you compare vanilla FO:NV to FO:3. New Vegas brings in the factions. You can be friendly with just about everyone to make the game easier but in being friends with say the NCR you are going to have to do alot that will  make the Legion mad at you. And factions play a huge role in whether or not you character is played the "right way" or wether it is not. For instance if you want to play a guns character NCR is probably the best way to go. If you want to play a meelee character I would say Legion. If you want to play an energy weapons character then I would say go with the Brotherhood of Steel/Independent(independent for the end of the game fighting the last part of the main quest on hoover dam with the robots on your side). Also this game doesn't bring back that many things from FO:3 its got some basic weapons but there are alot more guns to choose from making every playthrough unique. There is an endless possibility to the playstyles you can do, you can be a chem addict, you can be a justice fighter fighting off of your own moral code in a city of sin, you can be a mercanary, its endless. You can even choose to be the lone wanderer. Also karma doesn't really have that big of an appearance in this game. The only way it affects you is if (for example) your karma with the NCR is good they will be nice to you and they may let you do more things then if you were neutral, also some factions will give you free things with a good karma disposition to them. If you have a bad disposition to a faction then they will most likely make quests involving that faction much harder and they will probably try to shoot you in the face and once you get a bad disposition with them it is not an easy task to bring it back up. You have to do just about every quest with them for them to think "this guys 'alright' I guess" if you want it to go back up once its low. You will never really regain that sense of THIS GUY IS OUR SAVIOR. Also if you have good karma with a faction like the NCR then their rival, The Legion, Will not like you and they will hunt you down, this is both because the NCR will have yous fight the Legion, because you are just helkping the NCR and if you are wearing NCR armor. Now onto mods. There are many visual mods and gameplay mods and they add so many unique features. I would not reccomend a heavily modded game it tends to remove the Wasteland feel of the game. I would only reccomend asthetic mods and mods that do not affect game play unless you are using Project Navada. Gameplay affecting mods would be mods that add guns to the game or mods that make the geme "harder" or "easier", If you are having trouble doing a quest, press escape and navigate your way to the difficulty and turn the diffculty down. But dying is part of fallout and I would only reccomend this if you have died 5 or more times on the same objective. Also this game has Iron Sights, which I think is amazing. FO:3 only has a zoom that kept the crosshair and there weren't really any "working" mods that would add crosshairs, accept for RH_IronSights. And in FO:NV you can use crosshairs which make the gameplay so much more emersive. Also if you played FO:3 with the FOWE mod (fallout wonderers edition) then you should probably pick up fallout Nevada Project for fallout NV it will do just about everything that FOWE did. But I have a guideline that I like to follow for Fallout, If the mod you are downloading makes the game any easier, then don't get it. Trust me you will have more fun play this game casually with beauty mods and emersion mods. This just about concludes my review and recomendations for this game.*** REPLAY ABILITY LVL 100 SO MANY CLASSES MIX EM MATCH EM DO WHAT YOU WANT ITS GREAT SO MANY THINGS TO DO RUSH THE STORY OR DO ALL SIDE QUESTS GUNS OR MELEE LAZORS OR EXPLOSIONS ***I give it a solid 10 Nuka Cola's out of 10.Its like skyrim... with guns

Posted: December 25, 2015
												UhNot too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes insteadIngredients:1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour3 tablespoons sugar1 tablespoon baking powder1/4 teaspoon salt1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg2 large eggs, at room temperature1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as neededNow to make it1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg.2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla.3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat.4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed.5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed.6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

												having played Fallout 3 (did everything to do in that game and it's DLC..yes even Anchorage..) and having a reasonable time,i decided to tackle New Vegas..i didn't expect it to be good since i had problems with 3 but i was gladly wrong,where Fallout 3 suffered The Elder Scrolls problem of having only 4 voice actors for everyone but important characters and (yes hate on me for it) a crap story which i couldn't get into,New Vegas fixes most of that,better voice acting,better music,better AI,ALOT of improvements when it comes to combat(Vats isn't as essential anymore because you can f*cking aim properly now instead of having the gun on the right of the screen -_-) melee combat is a bit on the weak side still it's better than 3's,diffrent ammo types also help for more diverse playstyles,it's in my honest opinion just a direct upgrade from 3,it does almost everything better,the only thing i would like to have seen is more buildings you could enter,a thing i loved doing in 3 because almost every building had it's own little story,New Vegas is also a bit smaller as 3 but with the introduction of factions and the fact that it's more of a "safer" place than the Capital Wasteland(and thank good the Brotherhood of Steel plays a small role..) makes sense i geuss,overall i just like it alot more than 3

content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												Even after the release of Fallout 4, I still find myself coming back to this game.  This game is the best of the modern Fallout RPG's.  It improves upon some of the more lackluster elements of Fallout 3 by having some more interesting venues to explore and removing the annoying green tinge to everything in the Wasteland, but still keeps some of the best RPG mechanics of this game that Fallout 4 will do away with, such as the karma and reputation systems.  There's memorable characters and locales to be seen in this game, and it is well worth the price of admission.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												Never before has a game made me feel so at home like Fallout New Vegas.  The atmosphere, design, story, combat, strategy, mechanics, etc. blend perfectly togther into a delectable post-apocolyptic RPG cocktail.  It is more family to me than my own damn family.  Sure, mom packed my school lunches, but Fallout threw me a duster that didn't make me look like a tool, a plasma rifle, and said "Here, my son.  Have a form of aimbot that makes sense and still doesn't ruin the skill aspect of the game."  Honestly, there are so few games out there that have the kind of planning this game does.  Wanna shoot that store owner to get his nice hat? Have fun not getting the one modification you need for a perfect weapon later on.  Wanna shoot up a city?  You better have saved, becuase half of the quests in the game are probably in there.  Literally every action has a reaction in this game -- it's tough, it's gritty, and I love it for that reason.  Not to mention how well a 1950's sci-fi action movie was dressed up to be embodied by lucky players like myself.  Not only this, but lasers and beams are just as effective as bullets and javelins; it's all up to the player to decide.  So do you love story and atmospher just as much as gratuituos violence?  Good, Bathesda has that.  It's called Fallout, and it loves its community as much as its community loves it back.

Would that they had spent all the effort wasted on Fallout 3 on this game.Recommend running with Nexus Mod Manager:http://www.nexusmods.com/skyrim/mods/modmanager/?Definitely add this mod:Project NevadaAnd set the difficulty UP!  :-)Removes food & water healing for starters.http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/40040/?Other mods I enjoyed (some of these are classed 'adult' on Nexus):World of Pain (adult - language)  More mobs in existing locations,  more locations. Adds an oddly out of place zone called the 'underground' that would be better off removed IMOI like the addition of more mobs, and some of the locations fit well in the game,  but others do not.http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/38719/?Warzones (adult - language) On and off map areas with huge pitched battles.Some of the battles are so huge it will cause your game to stutter and/or crash.  There is a setting in the mod do regulate the size of battles if this is a problem.http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/40980/?Fellout Alters world tint and lighting.  Night is *DARK*  be sure to use the night vison from Project Nevada.I like the idea of darker nights - it makes the night perk, and the night vision from PN useful.http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/34888/?Yams Pinup Parade Adds huge numbers of period posters, ads and pinups to the game in various places.You really need to add this mod,  it adds a ton of color and richness to the game.  It's much more than pinups.http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/43341/?Lauren's Bathroom Poetry (adult? puerile, but funny)Adds permanent marker 'poetry' and 'wisdom' to public bathrooms across the wasteland.What public bathroom is complete without scrawlings from the shithouse poet?http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/41961/?Wasteland Flora Overhaul More plants, trees & grass for a greener wasteland.Make Nevada look more like Nevada.http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/39856/?Pin-Up playing card decks! Adds a unique deck of 50's pinup playing cards for each casino.Well rendered.  Makes Caravan even more interesting.(Caravan is actually a fun game once you figure out the interface!)http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/43734/?Any mod that allows Bottling Water (the one I use is outdated and unavailable)Any mod that improves ammo breakdown and creation (the one I use is outdated and unavailable)Also take a look at New Vegas Bounties I & III enjoyed them,  but found the dialogue in 'I' overly verbose.  Full of surprises. They are *fully voiced* amateur mods.If you're interested,  msg me about a period 1.35Gb ~19hr background playlist complete with public service announcements and advertisements.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												A typical day in the Mojave wasteland - I woke up in my dirty matress and took a drink form the nearby radioactive pond where I had recently shot a bunch of legionaier soilders. After getting dressed in my power armour attitre I was abducted by robots and asked to stop another robot controling more robots. After being returned to the fleshy world I decided to help liberate a village from marauders return thier livestock and kill a traitor amist them after which I was rewared with a few pieces of massive cockroach and mutated rats♥♥♥♥♥♥ While nomming on my new found lunch, my stomach started to make strange noises, it was then I decieded to seek a docter about my unnatural levels of radiation. On my way to see the docter I stoped over in the nearest city to stock up on ammunion and repiar my equipment. Unfourtnaty the city had been taken over by bandits. After repeditive death after another, I managed to clear out the city allowing its inhabitants to atend to me and my new found partner. Finally, after hours of treking through the nuclear wasteland, I reached a docter who was willing to treat my radiation. Thats just an hour worth of gameplay :P

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												War.War never changes.Except we actually have a active world and we can aim weapons! Anyways, Fallout New Vegas is a shining example of open world. You want to go to a NCR area and try and kill the troops for armor and guns? Go ahead, just good luck doing that. Or will you rush a cave filled with hard enemies to get that powerful rare weapon? Also, hardcore mode makes it so you have to eat sleep and drink, and as such it is a much easier game to roleplay.The nexus mod manager (or fomm if you want) will quickly become your best friend (and enemy) after your first playthough, as you can install many mods with ease.My main gripe with this game is that it is so BADLY OPTIMISED.Like jesus christ, my computer is rather beefy (can run bf3 1080p maxed, and bf4 1080p on medium with above 60 fps) and it still chugs like a fat person at the bacon buffet, also the lag spikes and glitches are really bad too, as you can go from a solid 60 to 10 just by walking around sometimes. Also the glitches can be super annoying, like a vital NPC will not talk to you, or you knowGet stuck in a cliff?This may be because I filled my game with mods. Great game, get it.Also DLCs are pretty good, just not as good at fallout 3's (in my opinion anyway)

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												First off; you don't need to play any of the other Fallout games to play this one. It's a fantastic standalone game that needs very little explanation: you're in a post-apocalyptic world where people are trying to pick up the pieces of the old world. You just got shot in the head after a botched courier job and find yourself being revived in the middle of the desert wasteland which you are going to explore in an FPS-perspective with a bunch of RPG-elements to make the game an overall fun and crazy experience.I'll keep it short, here we go:GOOD+ The mix of shooter and roleplaying game is almost perfect. Leveling up is fun and it feels great to explore all the possibilities. Which means: REPLAY VALUE. Yay!+ The world and enemies are interesting and fun. The western theme works surprisingly well and you'll definetly find some NPC's you'll fall in love with, while others you will definetly hate. Lots of personality going on!+ THE BEST DLC EVER. I'm not talking about a few extra weapons or missions, these are total expansions adding new things to every part of the game. Old World Blues being my definite favourite, but they're all worthy of purchase! This is how DLC should be done!+ Mods. Mods. Mods. The Modding community is great and they can give you almost unlimited ways to change your game for the better! (Or worse, if you really want that)NOT SO GOOD- Graphics aren't great, epecially on lower settings. Mods fix this, but the vanilla game just isn't very pretty. Visual glitches are quite common too, I suggest patching the game completely before playing.-  The game is huge, which means you will surely run into some bugs and glitches. Be sure to patch your game, but it might still have some stuff that annoys you, which breaks emersion.- Not the most immersive of RPG's, but your mileage may vary.- Friendly companions have the common problems of being suicidal and having bad pathfinding. They're interesting characters, but sadly not very usefull. (most of them)- Some features like crafting are basically useless aside from some specific missions. Unless you buy the DLC, they improve the use of crafting somewhat.So if you weren't sure wether you should buy this game or not, I say give it a try! It might have a few issues but there is A LOT to love about it. And if you're into modding your game, then this is another playground to go nuts in.I'll see you in the wasteland!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Wow, the big one. Okay, here we go. In the interest of being objective, I may be slightly biased with this review. I have loved many of the past Fallout games and it may colour my review.Fallout: New Vegas is the follow up to the critically acclaimed Fallout 3. It's history is long. It was originally Fallout 3 when it was going to be in the same style to Fallout 1 & 2. We are able to get the storys originally wanted in fallout 3 (Codenamed Van Buren) now, because many of the developers of Van Buren set up Obsidion Interactive. Now with the backstory out of the way, How does the game play?It runs on the Gamebryo engine and handles similar to fallout 3, with each weapon having a unique feel, sound and uses. The player moves at a reasonable speed, and nothing seems out of place in terms of controls.World spaceIn contrast to Fallout 3, the world is not very interesting on it's own. The story is where the game hits its stride.Speaking of StoryIt seems that this is the inverse to Fallout 3. FNV has amazing story, with sub-par world space. while F3 has sub-par story with amazing world space.Which to get, F3 or FNVAs a player of the original Fallout games, FNV hits the perfect spot between F2 and F3 for me. If you never played the original Fallout games, it is really just a coin toss. They go dirt cheep on sales so you don't lose much if you don't like one.Downloadable ContentFNV has an overall good selection of DLC, with Dead Money, Gun Runners Arsenal and Courier's Stash falling flat, but Honest Hearts, Lonesome Road and Old World Blues being some of the best I've ever played.

												Do I recommend Fallout: New Vegas? Yes. New Vegas is a great game, with lots of variety for anyone who is a fan of RPGs. However, get mods. Mods will not only help make the game function better (bug fix mods are a must) but they help extend the life of the game for several playthroughs. Also, if you don't believe that this game has replay value, I have over 800 hours into this game on the PS3, and modding the game is only helping to make it better. I personally recomend you get Ultimate Edition, as the DLC is some of the best in a video game, period.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2013
												I have been playing Fallout from part 3 and I did find Fallout NV something refreshing and not like the Vault Boy stereotype. New Vegas gave more enrichment to the game saga with info on the "Brotherhood Out West" and details on the origin of various wasteland species ( specific to NV though). The only change to the series is the change in possible endings - none of them, in my opinion, is quite satisfactory, yet not all that bad if you think about it. Possible spoiler: Fallout 3 fans love the Brotherhood of Steel of the Capital Wasteland and the possible extinction of the NV chapter of the BoS in the possible endings do not go down well. I am sure that is the bitter pill in all this even though both Chapters are quite different in their ideologies. The BoS in FNV is closest in comparison to th Capital Wasteland Outcasts.The new species and communites (including Jacobstown which is quite a good addition to the story if not very expansive towards storyline ) and the major factions trying to grab power in the Mojave forces the player to step carefully while choosing allies and making various decisions that affect the outcome of this story.The DLCs are...well...okay, I guess. Not very major or something to rave about but sits comfortably with the main storyline.The only reason why I have an isane 700+ hours in this game is because of the Fallout community and modding. Get yor character to play as Deadpool or the Terminator. Better yet - Chuck Norris! Have Mass Effect Cerebrus textured sentry bots. Heck, have your own pet Death Claw who can carry out a conversation with you or let him loose to rip your enemies to shreds. With modding, this game has taken off with a new lease of life. The only issue with the Fallout games is that they are quiet buggy and tend to freeze or just plain crash. For this there are mods and various solutions. Anyway, come what may, I am still a big fan of this series and recommend this game.

This has given me hours of enjoyment and equal amounts of horror at the stories of the wasteland. Also, you can still drink dirty water and do drugs that you find on the floor.

Shot in the head, left for dead, and already a hand in the total demise of two pre-nuclear apocalypse towns, the Courier's got it cut out rough from the start.War, War Never ChangesIt's been just over two-hundred years since the world burned in the atomic fire of the Great War in late October, 2077. One-hundred twenty years since the Vault Dweller left V13. Thirty-nine years since the Chosen One was sent out to save Arroyo. Four since the Lone Wanderer left V101 in search of their father. 2281 is the year you are ambushed and shot in the head. Odd, it seems, for the simple delivery of a poker chip...You're the Courier. Courier Six, of six, a delivery runner for the Mojave Express. You're a nobody. You're a wastelander. You have no say. But now you're at the center of the oldest power struggle in Las Vegas, and a major player in the current war over Hoover Dam.And you're not about to let a little bullet kill you.- -Fallout New Vegas pulls back to the olden days of Fallout, before ugly Tactics, unmentionable Brotherhood of Steel, and quasi-decent Fallout 3. It's cowboy, it's retrofuturistic, it's got really silly humor in the cracks of apocalyptic deconstruction of modern politics.The game itself plays much like Fallout 3, or Oblivion, or even the newer Skyrim. Awkward menu screens, slow response at times, and an engine that'd make GoldSource weep. The worldspace isn't fantastic, but has some really neat sights and landmarks based off of real-world locations. The combat is also much improved on over Fallout 3 - no more standing around in one spot smashing the fire key, you've got to use tact (or hellfire movement) to keep combat from killing you. It gets way easy at high levels, though.However, New Vegas is more about story. It's actually got four different branches to the main ending, with a few dozen more side-quest endings! There are quests galore in this game, all hidden around the world and within certain factions. I still find new ones, and I'm on my fourth playthrough with upwards of 650 hours! (A waste, maybe, but it's actually gotten me to DRIVE to Vegas to see the sights)There's the NCR, who were in Fallout 2, and sort-of in the original. A democratic, California-based minicountry that is pushing Eastwards for land and profit. They're overstretched and are having no end to troubles, as are the locals, who often complain about NCR taxes.The Legion is next. Caesar's Legion. A military machine of 87 enslaved tribes built in the image of Rome's Empire. A dictatorship run by a previous Follower of the Apocalypse, Edward Sallow, now calling himself Caesar and nursing a brain tumor. Yeah, he's a bit off his gourd, and an egomaniac.Robert House is another faction. A pre-war business magnate and overall genius when it comes to mathematics, House entombed himself and Vegas, to sleep over the war, per-say. Really, it was a coma caused by software crashes when the Lucky 38 nuclear defense system was activated to save Vegas, which could've been avoided with a certain Platinum Chip.Then there's Yes Man, or the Independent faction. This one is especially interesting because, while playing much like House, it's by the player's own thoughts and feelings. Don't like the BoS? Blow 'em up! Or don't, if you like them.The whole plot is about the Courier, Courier Six of six, who were sent out with packages to Vegas, each holding some kind of playing piece. Six was holding the Platinum Chip, which House needed for his software upgrade. Benny and his goons, the Chairmen, want the chip for their own so they can take full power of the Strip. It gets much more split-off after that, and, well, getting shot in the face. Twice. Oh, and there's a war going on between the NCR and Legion over the power/water at Hoover Dam and Lake Mead, but that's a whole chunk of later story.You can decide a faction, though you might be swindled up by House, or NCR, or even Legion, depending on who you bump into and how they strike you. The game gives you plenty of time before mentioning a decision needing made, so you can play the first few quests of each faction safely.There's also the side quests, which are more often linked to small factions like the Brotherhood of Steel, the Followers of the Apocalypse, or maybe one of the few towns in-game, like Goodsprings, Novac, or Jacobstown. These make up the meat of the game, since you'll likely pass through each of them.You also get a decent array of unique, quest-involved companions to drag along. I think there's nine in all, and you can take one humanoid and one non-humanoid companion at a time. There's a dog and a robot who act as secondaries, and they actually have very well-done quests involved in their companionship. But a lot of the triggers for these quests are hidden, so be sure to take everybody everywhere, and listen to everything they say.On top of ALL OF THAT, you get to customize your own character and, left with minimal history to the Courier, decide who they are. The core of a good RPG, if you ask me. Even better than the original Fallouts, with their scary Albert and... that big guy... and, uhm... I only remember Albert. Sorry, Interplay, your characters weren't memorable.The SPECIAL stats remain in, and new perks/traits have arrived with New Vegas. There's so many, though, that I won't go too deeply into them. Just be sure to consider Wild Wasteland. It adds some comic relief to the post-nuclear political state of New Vegas.So, uh, yeah. I feel my playtime speaks for itself. If you like RPG/Shooters, with lots of time to kill, then New Vegas is a good one to get. It's old, now, but the modding community is active, and kept well alive by Gopher, the Skyrim mod guru, and AlChestBreach, the man who made New Vegas (not really, he's just some Long Islander who talks to himself in funny voices).New Vegas. 9/10, for glorious story telling, political simulation, a bad engine, and old ladies beating me up in an alley.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Wow, the big one. Okay, here we go. In the interest of being objective, I may be slightly biased with this review. I have loved many of the past Fallout games and it may colour my review.Fallout: New Vegas is the follow up to the critically acclaimed Fallout 3. It's history is long. It was originally Fallout 3 when it was going to be in the same style to Fallout 1 & 2. We are able to get the storys originally wanted in fallout 3 (Codenamed Van Buren) now, because many of the developers of Van Buren set up Obsidion Interactive. Now with the backstory out of the way, How does the game play?It runs on the Gamebryo engine and handles similar to fallout 3, with each weapon having a unique feel, sound and uses. The player moves at a reasonable speed, and nothing seems out of place in terms of controls.World spaceIn contrast to Fallout 3, the world is not very interesting on it's own. The story is where the game hits its stride.Speaking of StoryIt seems that this is the inverse to Fallout 3. FNV has amazing story, with sub-par world space. while F3 has sub-par story with amazing world space.Which to get, F3 or FNVAs a player of the original Fallout games, FNV hits the perfect spot between F2 and F3 for me. If you never played the original Fallout games, it is really just a coin toss. They go dirt cheep on sales so you don't lose much if you don't like one.Downloadable ContentFNV has an overall good selection of DLC, with Dead Money, Gun Runners Arsenal and Courier's Stash falling flat, but Honest Hearts, Lonesome Road and Old World Blues being some of the best I've ever played.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2014
												My first experience with the Fallout series went well thanks to this game. The story of a war after a Great War is very interesting, and the freedom that you can choose any faction you want to join or simply fight them all and take over the Mojave for yourself proves its RPG elements. The city of Vegas itself is buzzing with lights at night, like its real-life counterpart albeit the scars of war. This game allows you to do things you will not do in real-life, massive killing sprees, drinking from a toilet bowl or urinal, its all so satisfying. The DLC's are also reccomended by me to enhance your experience with this game even more.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2012
												This is the game that Fallout 3 should have been.  Would that they had spent all the effort wasted on Fallout 3 on this game.Recommend running with Nexus Mod Manager:http://www.nexusmods.com/skyrim/mods/modmanager/?Definitely add this mod:Project NevadaAnd set the difficulty UP!  :-)Removes food & water healing for starters.http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/40040/?Other mods I enjoyed (some of these are classed 'adult' on Nexus):World of Pain (adult - language)  More mobs in existing locations,  more locations. Adds an oddly out of place zone called the 'underground' that would be better off removed IMOI like the addition of more mobs, and some of the locations fit well in the game,  but others do not.http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/38719/?Warzones (adult - language) On and off map areas with huge pitched battles.Some of the battles are so huge it will cause your game to stutter and/or crash.  There is a setting in the mod do regulate the size of battles if this is a problem.http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/40980/?Fellout Alters world tint and lighting.  Night is *DARK*  be sure to use the night vison from Project Nevada.I like the idea of darker nights - it makes the night perk, and the night vision from PN useful.http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/34888/?Yams Pinup Parade Adds huge numbers of period posters, ads and pinups to the game in various places.You really need to add this mod,  it adds a ton of color and richness to the game.  It's much more than pinups.http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/43341/?Lauren's Bathroom Poetry (adult? puerile, but funny)Adds permanent marker 'poetry' and 'wisdom' to public bathrooms across the wasteland.What public bathroom is complete without scrawlings from the shithouse poet?http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/41961/?Wasteland Flora Overhaul More plants, trees & grass for a greener wasteland.Make Nevada look more like Nevada.http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/39856/?Pin-Up playing card decks! Adds a unique deck of 50's pinup playing cards for each casino.Well rendered.  Makes Caravan even more interesting.(Caravan is actually a fun game once you figure out the interface!)http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/43734/?Any mod that allows Bottling Water (the one I use is outdated and unavailable)Any mod that improves ammo breakdown and creation (the one I use is outdated and unavailable)Also take a look at New Vegas Bounties I & III enjoyed them,  but found the dialogue in 'I' overly verbose.  Full of surprises. They are *fully voiced* amateur mods.If you're interested,  msg me about a period 1.35Gb ~19hr background playlist complete with public service announcements and advertisements.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
												As one of the first, modern open-world RPGs I've been able to play in a LONG while, Fallout: New Vegas has got me hooked. As the first Fallout game I've ever owned and played, I guess I can't say too much about New Vegas in comparison to its predecessors, but I think the game is just amazing overall. So far, the main story is great, the combat is spread out and fun, and there's just a lot to do. I would say that a half of the time I've spent playing the game I've been exploring the landscape for loot and discovering new places that aren't on the map which then leads to new quests. Character development is also another enjoyable factor of the game I've found whether you're going with a stealthy, assassin like character or a full out explosives one. Much like what Bethesda did in Skyrim, all the choices are yours to make.Although I have played this game for quite a bit of time (some will probably disagree, like those with 400+), I feel like I have barely scratched the surface of this game. I'm looking forward to finishing it in the future and then eagerly waiting for Fallout 4's release9.5/10

The story of a war after a Great War is very interesting, and the freedom that you can choose any faction you want to join or simply fight them all and take over the Mojave for yourself proves its RPG elements. The city of Vegas itself is buzzing with lights at night, like its real-life counterpart albeit the scars of war. This game allows you to do things you will not do in real-life, massive killing sprees, drinking from a toilet bowl or urinal, its all so satisfying. The DLC's are also reccomended by me to enhance your experience with this game even more.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2013
												At the start of this year, Fallout: New Vegas was hands-down the game I'd put more time into than any other, at least within the last ten years.  I'd put more than four hundred hours into the Xbox version over the course of several playthroughs.  After my time with the Xbox version, I would still hear the Mojave's siren call as I wandered the tundras of Skyrim, the streets of Columbia, the alleys of Dunwall, and many other fantastic places games took me.  Recently, I returned to walk the wastes as The Courier.  And according to Steam, I've put over 120 hours into my latest playthrough, all within a month's time.Given all this, I feel comfortable saying that I'm crazy about this game.  It isn't perfect.  It can be frustrating.  Even three years after its release, it's still a buggy mess at times.  Nonetheless, I love this game.My experiences aside: I'd encourage you to take a visit to the Mojave wastes.  Maybe our paths will cross along the Lonesome Road in a land beset by war.  And as we all know - war: war never changes.
