content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												This is probably the closest thing I have to a favorite game. I spend a lot of time drifting from favorites to favorites; some days it's Deus Ex, somedays it's Planescape: Torment. This is a game that I always come back to no matter what because it has everything I really want in a game.- Active modding community.- Well-written story that's faithful to its predecessors.- Opportunity for completionists and roleplayers alike.- Ability to kill very nearly everyone you meet (even story characters!).- Interesting characters (don't get me wrong, I like Fallout 3 but the characters all have the personality of sandpaper).- Infinitely replayable.- Ambient music, as well as some old-timey Vegas music. And Marty Robbins, if that's what you're into.- Actually fun (fun is this crazy new concept in the game world that is, contrary to popular belief, NOT synonymous to overpriced downloadable content).So as not to sound like a blind fanboy, I'll also fault the game on a few issues.- While this game allows you to develop your character as you choose, I will admit that everything leading up to Freeside/New Vegas feels relatively railroady (as in you're not forced to go forward, that's just where all the action is and there's no good reason not to go forward). Not that this is a major issue, as Fallout 1 and 2 were the same way.- Crazy amount of bugs. Like, game-breakingly bad bugs. Some bugs can render the game unplayable, and you may need to reload a save. If you're like me and you tend to play RPG's late at night, you might find yourself getting nightmares from the following bugs:* Dogs with floating eyes!* String cheese people!* Game freezing while really eerie music plays and you're in an underground bunker surrounded by feral ghouls, and all you can hear is a repeated sound clip of their ghastly taunts!* FalloutNV.exe has stopped working.Thankfully, many of these can be fixed with patches, then broken again with the next twenty mods you inevitably add right after.- Sub-par graphics, but they're passable enough to ignore and there's plenty of community-made ENBs, patches, and graphical tweaks.- The engine isn't great, but it's VERY popular with modders. Some people can accomplish amazing things with it, just look at some of the quest mods.Overall, this is the only game I've ever played that I would give a 10/10. Any issues I find that I have a problem with can be patched and improved. This game is extremely addictive, and I have given it at least 500 hours of gameplay when my time playing it on PS3 is taken into consideration.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2016
												An excellent game. This review is going to be presented very loosely, sorry. I had owned this game before but decided to get it on steam.There's all sorts of tales this game is waiting to tell. Accepting to do a quest which may seem intriguing at the time may not later as it'll sacrifice others which may seem more worth your time; for example, a companion insists that we take down two big companies as they had done something cruel, however doing this will remove the chance to converse with a myriad of interesting characters, which when killing them, may feel like beating up petty dogs- because you hadn't found out their ambitions and characteristics. The game is tailored to the whims of the player and makes you try to justify your actions in order to avoid feeling regretful. Any game can do this on paper, but to make it this enrapturing, requires a team that's dedicated to setting a benchmark instead of satisfying greedy shareholders. This paragraph also highlights the replayability of the game.The quests are intertwined into a bigger system often making you meet new npcs- they give you a better grasp of the motives of the factions and will give you the neccessary information to make your mind up about the ultimate ending. Go through computers and tapes as these tend to be fleshed out with stories. Another example: There's a staff complaint about the unexpected shipment of stealthboys, as some mischievous staff have been using them to satisfy their curious minds, or perverted in this case.I find the unsettling atmosphere to be very engrossing: the sun soaked visuals, rough tarnished surfaces along with the ambient sounds and fallout's occoasional press of a sombre piano key blend in to make New Vegas a belivable wasteland.More songs on the radio(s) would be nice( mods could sort this out though) but then again you'll spend quite a  bit of time in combat, so listening carefully to your surroundings will help and reward you. You may find this game frustrating on harder difficulties when you're suddenly outnumbered and your skills don't seem to be paying off. You're suddenly relying on vats more often to get the dirty work done, and when you're out of it, you're spamming your favorite pistol- which till now had been working wonders just isn't so you're dead. There's always a way avoid these situations.  This is a role playing game in which all the mechanics and options to manevoure a tricky situation in your favour have been realised. If you think not, there's an abundence of mods out there that are dedicated to polishing this gem.Luckily for me, I played this long after the launch date so I've very rarely encountered bugs and I am playing without mods, which i should have a look at.The game truly has spurs that jingle jangle jingle: there's always something which keeps me coming.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2016
												(Ignore low playtime, had a disc when I first got it and re-bought the Steam version)This game is excellent.  This is one of the best video games I've ever played, the best Fallout game by far, and a massive accomplishment.  The story is great.  The game lets you play the way you want to play - if you decide you don't want to gun down everything in FPS style, you can negotiate, backstab, and compromise your way through objectives.  The array of side quests and interesting diversion is massive. The mod community basically built another game on top of this one, so you're getting far more than the sticker price.  The DLC ranges from zany fun (Old World Blues) to heartbreaking (Dead Money) to abysmally grim (Lonesome Road).  This is one of the best games I've ever played. I can't recommend it enough.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Fallout New Vegas is a game in the Fallout Universe that takes place in 2281, 4 years after the events of Fallout 3. You are a courier hired by the Mojave Express to deliver a secret package to Mr.House in New Vegas. A casino manager by the name of Benny wants the?package to take over Vegas so he finds you with aid of the Great Kahns (one of the tribes in the Mojave Wasteland, Benny takes the package (soon to be know as a Platinum Chip) (The Chip can override the securitrons, Robots that protect Vegas. Anyways Benny shoots you in the head and buries you in the Goodsprings Cemetary, a securitron named Victor digs you out of the grave and takes you to the Goodsprings doctor , Doc Mitchell.So you wake up in the Doc's home and you set up your character and all that, After you leave the doctors home you can go to the "Prospectors Saloon" and meet a girl named "Sunny Smiles" she will give you a gun and let you do target training. In the Mojave Wasteland you can do quests for four opposite factions : NCR (a military army that tries to bring good across the Wasteland), The Legion (a group of slavers, evil people led by Caesar), Yes Man (a securitron?reprogrammed by Benny that would help him take over Vegas), Mr.House (the father of New Vegas who protected most of Vegas from the nukes of the Great War of 2077) The game is addictive so much greatness, you can do quests for people across the wasteland to earn caps, weapons and good or bad karma. I highly recommend the game if you are a fan of Fallout 3 or the past Fallout games, the game is not really that difficult it depends if you are new to Fallout or not. Sounds are great but the game full of npc's should have more voice actors, Graphics are awesome, The game offers a lot especially the DLC's Just be warned the "Dead Money" DLC will fill you with rageThe DLC's are:Lonesome Road Honest HeartsOld World BluesDead MoneyCourier's StashGun Runners ArsenalIf you want  a game thats $10 i highly recommend this games $10 is almost a steal

content:
Posted: October 13, 2012
												The younger and more attractive sister of Fallout 3, New Vegas takes pretty much everything 3 does and makes it better. The gameplay is better, the story has more depth to it, and the setting is just wonderful. It's also worth noting that FO3 wasn't 100% accurate to the FO lore, whereas this isn't the case with FONV.If you're familiar with FO3, FONV's gameplay is basically the same, with a few neat additions. If you're not, think of an FPS mixed with an open world action RPG that's broken up by dialog choices and searching for stuff. It really gets at the survivalist mentality that a lot of people seem to be getting into these days.Where FONV differs from the original, outside the obvious gameplay additions, is the story elements. The characters really feel alive in FONV, there's a real charm that New Vegas has that just makes you fall in love. I wish I had more room to talk about it, the FEEL of the game is just so fantastic.Anyway, I highly recommend this game. Highly replayable.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												When it comes to the Fallout games, the biggest questions you need to ask yourself usually consist of "Is it still canon?", "Is it really that moddable?", and probably "Is it enjoyable?". Rather fortunately for New Vegas, the answers tend to be yes.The franchise itself is not without some tarnish (looking at the PS2 and Xbox game I'm not fond of mentioning!) but New Vegas is more than capable of delivering the brand from the dark, gritty, heavy metal future it was careening into and taking the series back to its roots: gratuitous sex, violence, political intrigue, and 1950's Americana.New Vegas isn't exactly a flawless jewel of the desert, though. It does have a rushed feel to the ending, like the majority of Obsidian's games (read: KotOR 2 and Alpha Protocol) and the game has an entire phylum of bugs indicitive of a Bethesda game. The game also lacks any sort of sandboxing continuity following the ending, a major flaw for a game this expansive. Play it, regardless.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												Fallout New Vegas is easily one of the most openworld, exciting, gritty games I have ever played. The choices, factions, graphics and wide range of weaponary and outcomes makes this game one of the most gripping, addictive and just simply incredible games out there on the market. You can go from being a sneaky, threatening terrorist working with Caesers legion to a brave, couragous mercanary trying to win independance for the citizens of the Mojave wasteland. Or if neither of these outcomes is to your liking; you can work with a rogue securitron and take over New Vegas for yourself. The sheer amount of gameplay avaliable makes this game unique, addictive and one of the best roleplay/action games of the decade.

												Very immersive; easy to sink many, many hours into this game. Great quests; loads of unique, fun-to-use weapons...quite a few  broken elements to the game though that I'm surprised have not yet been patched/fixed yet. For example, some quests must be completed in a certain order, despite the open-world nature of the game. Can be very frustrating to either go back to an earlier save and complete the quests in the correct order or to find out the console commands to bypass the glitch. Better than Fallout 3 I think, if not simply because it's much less depressing/bleak and it seems like there's a greater density of interest points, or whatever the locations on the map are called. I recommend this game, very fun. DLC is worth it, too!

												i take back what i said a year ago, its worth more than one playthrough, and its good. since i first played it a year ago, i liked it, but then started fallout 3 to find that i enjoyed that one more due to its brutality but i never finished that game. fastforward a year and ive got ~25 hours in skyrim and i need something that is a little less, overwhelming.i reinstalled the game to not only find out that new vegas has cloud support, but that i dumped ~80 hours into the base campaign (well, minus th very last main story quest...) and 2 of the add-on/dlc's ("honest hearts" & "old world blues", both of which i loved); and acording to the wiki, i still got half a map to go through and a look at my pip boy says i got several loose ends to tie up. best part is i get to brave through it with some horrible jack of all trades character i couldnt get to work properly!the only real things i still dislike about the game is cazadores (huge amber wing-colored flies that move at the speed of light compared to your annoying snail's pace), simplistic difficulty setup (needing 300 bullets to kill one creature isnt hard, its just boring, time AND resource-consuming, not making a creative way to ramp up the difficulty of a single-player game just makes the game a drag for those who want a challenge), and the fact that you cant continue to play once you finish the game. thats all i can say that's bad about this game, so buy the ultimate edition now!

content:

												What is there to say about the absolutely best game that has ever been created, except that it is the best game ever made?Perhaps that the game is epic in every way possible, that the story is increadibly deep, that there is almost too many guns for you to possible obtain in one gameplay... Wait.. That last one is probably false. But even if you could collect every weapon in the entire game, you sure as hell would never EVER be able to carry all of them. Now where was I?   Yes, there!*clears throat*That you can install mods on most of your weapons, as long as you  have the ultra-cheap DLC "Gun Runners Arsenal", that you can blow/shoot/chop peoples arms/legs/heads of, that you can craft both ammunition and various tools and explosives, that every weapon and armor in the game has got a durability, which means that it will break after you've used it a lot, that the game is increadibly entertaining, humoristic, and silly over all, and of course, that YOU decide exactly what you want to do.If you haven't bought it already, you really should.I assure you, it's worth the money to 110%BUTThere is one downside.The game, at least if you are like me, is addictive as hell.Once I start playing it, it's almost impossible to stop.I guess this pretty much wraps it all up.Also, If you've read this far, you've got to buy the game, or else you and all your family will be brutally butchered while asleep.Good night!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												Fallout: New Vegas is a good game, maybe even a better game than Fallout 3, and here's why. Pros: - The best thing about this game is the music. It's upbeat and hilarious. Even if you're not normally a fan of songs about homicidal cowboys, a lot of these classic 40's and 50's tunes will get stuck in your head all day nonetheless.- The Mojave is a vibrant, interesting background for the kinds of fun shenanigans that make Bethesda games a blast.- The characters in this game are great, and in many ways more interesting than the characters in Fallout 3. - The game engine now allows you to aim using iron sights, as well as a time-freezing mechanic called "V.A.T.S." Fallout 3 had only V.A.T.S., no iron sights. - Enemies are more varied and interesting than the same old rehashed enemy types from Fallout 3. Now you can kill "giant flies" and "glorified LARPers in Roman armor made from football gear", as well as the tried and true "radioactive zombies" and "giant scorpions."- There's a big modding community that's put a lot of work into creating free content to extend your wasteland experience even further. Sometimes the mods are even as good as the content in the vanilla game.Cons: - It's a Bethesda game. Luckily by now most of the bugs have been patched, or can be patched if you download a few mods from the Mod Nexus. But still, buggy, crashy, sometimes laggy. - The story's a bit meh. Even though the characters are, IMO, better than Fallout 3's, the story isn't quite as fulfilling or engaging. All around, New Vegas is a lovely game with a beautiful soundtrack and a lot of really fun elements to it. Another masterful example of the RPG genre from Bethesda.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2012
												If you haven't bought this, well, then you're a complete silly since this is one of the best games I've ever played. Fallout New Vegas combines the amazing sprawling open world gameplay of Fallout 3, but mixes in the atmosphere of the first 2 games, making the ultimate Fallout experence. Fans of the first games will feel right at home, and fans who played 3 only will love this to death. The storyline is an incredibly cool power struggle between 3 factions warring for control of Hoover Dam, and ultimately New Vegas itself. New Vegas is the last beacon of humanity, a city untouched by nuclear holocaust. You play a Courier, assigned to deliver a package to New Vegas, when you are shot in the head and left for dead. And so begins a tale of revenge and power. Gameplay is almost identical to Fallout 3, with a few new features. The DLC is great, and it's just fantastic. Buy this now.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												Fallout New Vegas:     FNV is an open world, action rpg set in a post-apocalyptic Mojave desert, with civilization starting to re-emerge out of the ashes. The fairly large map (21 square miles) surrounds one of the few places doing relatively well in the wasteland: Vegas. The landscape in vegas can sometimes be a bore, with a lot of dry rolling hills around you, but the excellent 30's, 40's, and 50's music will make you forget all that, and just hum along.      Story wise, FNV is not amazing, but still good. In the opening cinematic, you, a simple courier for the mojave express company, gets shot straight in the head by a suave, but evil and cocky son-of-a-gun fellow named Benny. Once you are healed in the nearby town of goodsprings, your new goal is to hunt him down and bring him to justice. The story brings the player around the whole map, greeting the player with dozens of side quests. Once the player finally does kill Benny, the story really takes off, allowing the player to join one of the three factions viyng for power, or take over by yourself. The three faction are :The New California Republic, a gorup wanting to bring back the world before the apocalypse, Ceasers legion, a crazy dicator bent on ruling like a roman emperor, and Mr.House, a high tech robot wanting to bring back the 'glory of vegas'.    Gameplay is where this game truly shines. With the old-school RPG like character creation complete with a plethora of unique and fun perks, you can create a variety of different classes, each with their own playstyle, allowing for a lot of replayability. There are dozens of different weapons varying from a simple smg, or an orbital strike cannon, or a plasma rifle, a super-sword thing, and dozens more. With the expansive map filled with locations ranging from a ski lodge with super-mutants, to deep vaults giant fire ants, the postapocalyptic world is a truly crazy place.      FNV is not perfect, though there are hundreds of bugs and glitches, which is to be expected with a game of this size. Some of the quests are bland, and some of the locations are quite small and boring. There seems to also be only a few voice actors, evenif thats not the case. Most of these problems can be fized with mods, which brings me to my next point:the excellent modding community. There are hundreds and thousands of mods on the nexus and various other sites, ranging from high quality lore friendly quests, to crazy weapon packs, graphical overhauls, spiderman cars, companion mods, bug fixes, to more risque things.     With the points made above, I strongly reccomend this game to anybody who loves rpg's action games, well written experiences, and pretty much anyone who has likes video games. I do not reccomend this to a completionist though, much like Skyrim, the buggy quests, and the sheer size of the game makes it quite hard to 100% complete, and maybe not in a good way. To anybody else that likes anything, by this game now.Score(do I need this?) = 8.5/10With mods = 9.5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												10/10Fallout 3 was more than a game for me, it was a revelation. The post-apocalyptic setting, deep customisation system, and engaging, witty, touching narrative captured my imagination from the first. I had played RPGs before, and shooters. I had played games that combined TPS/FPS and RPG - games like Bioshock and Dead Space that, though brilliant, did not have the massive sandbox immersion of Fallout. (Criminally, it would be some time before the already-released-at-that-time Shadow of Chernobyl came to my attention.)  Initially Fallout 3's combat felt jagged. TPS, FPS, V.A.T.S., real-time, etc., the number of mechanics seemed to diffuse the combat experience. However I soon settled into the FPS perspective and developed an appreciation for the turn-based flavour V.A.T.S. leant the game. By the time I moved on from Fallout 3 I'd invested 60 hours in the game. By nature a serial monogamist, for me every game I'm playing is, for the time I'm playing it, the only game I'll ever play. And for Fallout 3 that felt a little more true than usual.For nearly a year after purchasing it, Fallout 3: New Vegas sat untouched in my Steam Library. I couldn't shake the fear that its Western styling would be overbearing and tacky, that it would take Fallout 3's brilliantly decrepit post-apocalyptia and riddle it with jerky-chewing cowboys, main-street shootouts, and robots with Texan accents. In the meantime I discovered a number of TPS/FPS-RPGs, games like Borderlands 2, that fed my habit in different ways - and it was after killing Handsome Jack for the fifth time that I turned my still suspicious eye back towards FO:NV My fears of a tacky western-themed cash-in - a sort of anti-Call of Juarez Gunslinger - were almost immediately put to bed. FO:NV inarguably occupies the same world as Fallout 3. The same Gamebryo engine and Havok physics are used by both games. NPCs, mobs, textures and buildings could equally well occupy either game, as could the UI and combat system. FO:NV doesn't just bring the nachos and beer to the party that a DLC might - rather, it fully caters an after-party with open bar, starting at midnight and running till - well, by the time I'd finished FO:NV, I'd happily plowed in an even 100 hours, 40 more than I had with Fallout 3, not just completing but completist-ing the game. Like Fallout 3, The New Vegas DLC are uneven. On the one hand, Old World Blues brings a large new area, rich characters, and a deep, witty, touching storyline. I personally enjoyed this DLC as much as or more than the game itself. Lonesome Road, though shorter, follows not far behind - a self-contained journey I loved every second of. On the other hand, Dead Money is a frustrating deviation from Fallout's tradition of open world gameplay. It forces the player down a very narrow channel indeed, and seems to do everything possible to prevent you from appreciating its hidden gems. It is fraught with cheap tricks and back-tracking, all set in a hopelessly clumsy and claustrophobic map.Fallout New Vegas, like Fallout 3 before it, is a generous game. Its enormous landscape is lousy with well-drawn characters, dark secrets and nascent adventure. The "sub-quests" (I hesitate to deprecate them with the prefix "sub") hanging off so many items, places and characters are the soul of FO:NV. Like life, even the "central" plot is a structure pieced together from numerous tangential sub-plots, each with its own flavour and authenticity. Also like life, the sub-plots that make up this structure are for you to choose, and are different from each and every perspective. Character composition is a true joy in New Vegas; honing your character throughout a thousand decisions, positioning your character according to a hundred others, deciding their stance towards dozens of factions. Morality is not limited to an overly-simplistic system, such as "positive" and "negative" karma points, or the like. Again, as it is in life, your character's ethics are something you will have to create and hone with every move you make. Perhaps even more so than Fallout 3 before it, New Vegas is a game where the real forum of character creation is not in the levelling of skills, the choosing of eye colour and kitting-out your armory - it is in playing the game itself.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Fallout: New Vegas transports the player to a completely different world. The introductory video will introduce you to people and factions who will become your greatest enemies and your best friends, but it's left up to you to decide who is who. Playing as an amensiac courier, you must piece together your own past, but when you have all the facts, it's time to decide the future. You face difficult choices that will influence the rest of the storyline which culminate in the Battle of Hoover Dam, but your story isn't over. A final video extends the stories of communities and characters well into the future based on your actions.The iconic Fallout style shows throughout the game, and many old factions are shown in a refreshing light. Each faction has a unique style, philosophy, and history, that can only be gleaned through extensive dialogue options.

Posted: June 30, 2016
												Fallout New Vegas; a cacophony of carnage.I freed the slaves underneath Caesar's boot, I helped bring back order to the NCR and annexed New Vegas for California. I roam the Wasteland of the Mojave bringing order into its system. I burnt out the deathclaw nests, I reopened trade routes for caravans, I've lined the raiders and bandits against the wall and promptly shot them dead.Yet every ♥♥♥♥ing time that karma meter says I've done a good thing.Through all the killing, all the lives I've ruined to save another, all the roads I had to take, to be renowned as a dirty mercenary, a hitman, killer-for-hire, a sinner. Is this the path I chose? A courier turned into vicious psychopath in the eyes of the public? A vicious brute to the Khans, a heretic to the Legion, a murderer to other wastelanders, a Grim Reaper to those without blood money. Is all this blood worth all these caps?Also, great game. Hard to put down, easy to pick up even after going a few months without playing.I prefer this one over Fallout 3. Haven't tried all the DLC yet but it just means I'll have a reason to keep playing after I do try it out, and before I forget."Patrolling the Mojave almost makes you wish for a nuclear winter."

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												One of my personal all-time favourites, Fallout: New Vegas is an amazing entry into the franchise. It includes great RPG elements and a fantastic storyline with several choices available for the player to become immersed in the massive and detailed frontier of the Mojave Wasteland, which has many locations and factions that the player can choose to side with- or destroy.An entertaining combat system is introduced, with iron sights and cinematic kills aided by the satisfying VATS.NPCs and companions are better than ever, as almost every character has their own unique tale to tell and can be linked with a large amount of side quests and unmarked quests, without over-using generic fetch quests and other repetitive mechanics to keep the player occupied.One of the best things about this game is the outstanding modding community, which keeps the game supplied with new content even today, 3 years after its release. From graphics enhancements to new quests, items, locations and characters, it can all be used to make this game even better. I highly recommend this game as it's worth every penny, especially right now with the current Steam sales.

												First off, don't believe all that stuff about the game running like♥♥♥♥♥♥ graphics being sucky, everything just being awful, it being boring, etc, etc. It's only boring if you try to have no fun. The wasteland is...Supposed to be a wasteland...Some parts...Are irradiated because they're supposed to be...Be a mann and wade through that radioactive sewage! Be a mann and kill those deathclaws! And if this game bores you, just do whatever the hell you want in it. Get power armor and blow up the BOS Bunker with 20200102001 dynamite, slash through hordes of ghouls, just murder everyone. And if murdering everyone and satisfying your bloodlust isn't enough, do it for the nostalgia. And if nostalgia isn't enough/doesn't exist, avoid this game.Gud?1. Many hours of gameplay, many places to explore.2. You get to do whatever you really want to do. Usually with consequences, but go ahead, kill everyone! It's fun!3. Mods. Are. Amazing.4. If you're like me, and are easily impressed by graphics and say Donkey Kong had the best graphics, well, then the graphics are on par with Donkey Kong. If you actually don't think Donkey Kong had the best graphics, then the graphics in this game are pretty good. If you're a stickler, decent. If you're a graphics ♥♥♥♥♥, awful. If you're a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, go die.5. So fun to explode people, dismember people...God, I am violent. Also, hardcore mode! Fun!Bad?1. You can only have two companions, one humanoid, one non-humanoid. Can be fixed with mods, so you get out there and make a glorious army!2. Nothing...Else?Please realise that this review is extremely biased. In a non-biased opinion, the game is exceptionally fun and has tremendous replay value if you enjoy exploring and RPGS, and action and stuff like that.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												New Vegas is the reason why I love listening to Frank Sinatra. Why? Because one thing this game taught me is that there is something magic in exploding heads with a Shotgun while listening to "Blue Moon". That's just a new level of awesomness.The start of NV is a little bit boring and cliche. Your character was shot, and you wake up with amnesia: "Why? Who? When? Where?" Nothing new to see here. The tutorial also doesn't make a good impression. Shoot some ugly creatures, talk with some folks, make a tour around, just to warm up and to prepare you for the greatness that awaits on the desert. When you step out of the first city,well...that's when things start getting interesting, specially with the V.a.t.s. shooting system by your side. It's time to see some heads exploding, arms getting ripped out, blood spilling all over you...That's when you know you are playing a Fallout game. But it's just 10% of it's awesomness. Everything in the desert seems to tell you a story: the buildings, the characters, the cities, the objects, life just seems to emanete from everything you encounter. The dialogue system flows so well and feels so good and charming that you will get attached to every creature you meet. The quests are also one strong point, because every single decision you make feels like it's changing the world around you, and the destiny of many characters you care about. Is it a perfect game then? No, it isn't. And you want to know why? Bethesda famous trademark, thatt's why...You know,bugs and ugly models. Since Bethesda is Bethesda, you know what's coming. But don't worry, it doesn't ruin the experience...not a single bit. I think it even makes it more charming.If you like to play games, buy Fallout New Vegas. Because when someone asks you "Why do you like playing games?", You will know what to answer: "Fallout New Vegas, mate". Believe me.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												I highly recommend this game, to anyone who likes action RPGs. One problem I have with it, is the games abundance of bugs and glitches. Compared to Fallout 3 there are a thousand times more bugs and glitches. Luckily, these problems can be easily fixed with unofficial patches and fixes provided by the modding community. Thanks, to the modding community the lifetime of this game has been increased greatly. One thing I liked most about Fallout: New vegas, is the similar features it shares with its predecessors Fallout 1 and 2, such as traits and getting perks every other level. Fallout 3 was the more stable game of the two, but Fallout: New Vegas gave old players of the franchise a nostalgic feel. Also, Fallout: New Vegas, gave players a wide variety of weapons to choose from, unique locations to visit, and brought back old characters, and factions. Whether you are a longtime Fallout fan or new to the series, you should strongly consider adding this game to your library.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
												Even though I don't have many hours on the PC version, I had hundreds on the PS3. This game is a step forward from FO3. Why? Well, factions are a big one. It's neat how choices you make will change the way a certain faction feels about you. for example, with Caesar's Legion and the NCR. If you decide to help the NCR, you will beocme hated by the Legion, and vice versa. Also, if you help certain factions, they will help you in the final fight at Hoover Dam (Example is the Boomers and the Great Kahns). Another big stepup is the the amount of new weapons and enemies there are. This game feels more story driven than the last, because you can carry it out in multiple ways. The only thing I can see that FO3 had better was that the Karma actually meant something when you play. Also, it can run on Windows 7. I definitley recommend this game to anyone who enjoys open-world games.

content:
Posted: March 9
												I played half an hour about two years ago and didn't get the feel of it. After watching a youtube video on how fallout 3 failed to live up to its predecessors (of which I am a huge fan), I gave it a shot.This game IS the real Fallout 3. -It has the humour of the original fallouts.-There is a difficulty curve, along an roughly expected path, unlike the levelling of Fallout 3/Skyrim, etc.-Quests are varied and interesting, with puzzles, rather than endless fetch quests.-The voice acting seems more varied for the most part, and, in the DLC, is quite frankly excellent (I'm looking at you, Old World Blues).-It has "Romanes eunt domus" painted on a legion base wall. This is worthy of a point in itself. -Morality is less black and white.-YOU are the main protagonist, rather than following your damn dad around. And revenge is a ♥♥♥♥♥. Just go get it alright? Grab it on a sale with all the DLC for under $10 and you certainly won't be disappointed, especially if you appreciated regular references to the places and people of Fallout 1 & 2 throughout your journey.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												Pros:-An extremely well written story with multiple endings that not only include the main factions but minor ones as well that makes each playthrough a little different. -Multiple character builds, melee, unarmed, guns, energy weapons, explosives or just a passive playthrough. -Four amazing DLC, the worst one is Dead Money but it's still worth playing through. -Extremely artistic dialogue that shows reason and logic on both poles of the political compass of New Vegas. -A well done playthrough will take at least 25 hours (45 or more doing the DLC)-Wide variety of weapons-Multiple ways to accomplish something. You want to get into a safe? You can pick lock it, hack into a terminal or loot the password off of the owner, etc. -Lots of side quests that make the content seem limitless. -Great Fallout 1 and 2 references that bring nostalgia back from the Windows 98 days. Cons:-There is a lot of unused map space, making it about 1/4 smaller than in Fallout 3-There's a ton of useless locations that serve no purpose other than just cluttering up the mini-map-Lack of voice actors makes conversations repititive. -Game is prone to crashing, rubber banding and audio skips-Issues with CTD'ing when I first purchased it. -Invisible walls in the game make traversing the waste land very annoying-Game is a lot more scripted than in Fallout 3-The main quest line is only fun the first time playing through. SPOILER ALERT: Basically, you're shot in the head and you're tracking down the guy that killed you and while you're tracking him down, you sometimes have to do side quests for people to get information on the whereabouts of your wouldbe assassin. The only reason you'd do these side quests on a second playthrough on up is for experience and for a longer ending. Other than that, they're useless. -I found the Vegas Strip to be an incredible let down. Throughout the game, they make it to be this big and marvelous place but when you get there, you're like "meh". 8.5/10Great game, worth every penny, just some minor issues that seem to bog it down from being perfect.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
												Overall, a great game and my personal favorite video game. Pros:-Interesting characters and quests-a true fallout game-improves on nearly every aspect of fallout 3-amazing, atmospheric soundtrack-loads of replay value (700+ hrs)-great modding community adds even more replay value-great level design across the board-good optimization-simplisticCons:-low-res, unappealing graphics, even for 2010-poor aiming and combat-main story isn't as engaging or interesting as fallout 3-buggyConclusion:A very unique and well done game that improves upon much of Fallout 3's shortcomings. If you didn't like 3, you probably won't like this game, either. Absolutely worth every dollar. There are so many different ways to approach quests & you can be any character you want: bad, good, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, whatever. There are a wide variety of guns and clothes to choose from. If you like this game at all, it can definitely suck your life away. Better than Fallout 4.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2012
												Set in a post-nuclear desert known as the Mojave Wasteland, you are a courier searching for the man who tried to kill you. Weapon sights, more varied perks, cooking and crafting systems, quirkier writing and a larger variety of gear and characters separate NV from Fallout 3. Unfortunately, the graphics are terrible (no environment shadows, muddy textures, undetailed meshes, and so on), AI is laughable, and combat is a mess of suicidal NPCs either strafing or standing completely still. Fortunately, combat isn't all - conversations and the choices you make are important. You'll be able to threaten, praise, blackmail and so on, influencing other people - alongside the impact that your skills, traits and perks also have. Sadly, most characters are boring or lifeless due to sloppy writing, terrible animations and sub-par voice acting. Plagued by design problems, bugs and a disappointing ending, NV is quantity over quality. It gets the job done, but it could have been a lot better.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2013
												What is there to say about the absolutely best game that has ever been created, except that it is the best game ever made?Perhaps that the game is epic in every way possible, that the story is increadibly deep, that there is almost too many guns for you to possible obtain in one gameplay... Wait.. That last one is probably false. But even if you could collect every weapon in the entire game, you sure as hell would never EVER be able to carry all of them. Now where was I?   Yes, there!*clears throat*That you can install mods on most of your weapons, as long as you  have the ultra-cheap DLC "Gun Runners Arsenal", that you can blow/shoot/chop peoples arms/legs/heads of, that you can craft both ammunition and various tools and explosives, that every weapon and armor in the game has got a durability, which means that it will break after you've used it a lot, that the game is increadibly entertaining, humoristic, and silly over all, and of course, that YOU decide exactly what you want to do.If you haven't bought it already, you really should.I assure you, it's worth the money to 110%BUTThere is one downside.The game, at least if you are like me, is addictive as hell.Once I start playing it, it's almost impossible to stop.I guess this pretty much wraps it all up.Also, If you've read this far, you've got to buy the game, or else you and all your family will be brutally butchered while asleep.Good night!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												This game... When it was released, I hated it. The map was smaller than 3's and it just didn't feel like how I wanted it to. But then as time went on and it seemed as if we were never going to get a Fallout 4, I came back to it, started modding it and really just enjoying the game for what it is. AND THEN, YEARS LATER.... FALLOUT 4 CAME OUT! While I did and still do enjoy FO4 from time to time, it really made me appreciate New Vegas. Fallout 4 has the huge map, the shooting mechanics and the great graphics, but where it failed is where New Vegas shines, in the gameplay, the RPG elements and actually good game mechanics. If you're looking for the REAL Fallout experience then play Fallout New Vegas, it's a great game with a HUGE modding community to keep you busy for hours and hours before or after you fininsh the main storyline depending on whether or not you're using CAGE (Continue After Game Ending). If you're having stuttering problems, get Fallout Stutter Remover. Want weapons? Check out the Millenia team on Nexus. If you're looking for a quest mod, check out the New Vegas Bounties series by Someguy2000. For those of you who are scared by the word "MODDING", as a grizzled modding veteran, here are a few tips I will give you.1. The first thing you should do for ALL BETHESDA GAMES is download the corresponding Script Extender for that game, for New Vegas it is NVSE.2. There are numerous tools you can (should) use to mod your game: Nexus Mod Manager/FallOut Mod Manager to install your mods for you and LOOT to manage your load order (which is the order by which your mods are loaded and if done incorrectly you will have compatability problems like missing textures or Crashes) but not to worry, LOOT will do that for you. 3.Then, there's FNVEdit, this tool is used for cleaning mods, and it requires a bit of modding know-how so for people new to modding, don't get this till you're a little more experienced.4. Don't feed the Yao Guai... That is all...Well.... I guess that's it then, To all you Fallout newcomers reading this: Enjoy the ride, it's going to be a long one, and to those, like me, who have devoted countless hours into playing and modding this game, I guess we've got a case of the Old World Blues.
